title: How does one differentiate between 'good' and 'bad' acting? - Quora

response.answer_text: Details from the original question: Could you give examples? I can't differentiate between the two. Everyone says Tom Cruise was bad in War of the Worlds or that he's an bad actor in general. But how is he bad in acting? I also don't find Philip Seymour Hoffman to be an "outstanding actor," like everyone else says he is. Whenever I see him acting, I see PSH acting not the person. The same with Meryl Streep. I don't see anything "convincing" or "great" in her acting. What's the difference between Tom Cruise's acting and PSH's acting?The only actor that blends in and that convinces me that he's a good actor is Daniel Day-Lewis. But that's it. If anyone tells you there are objective standards, they're full of shit. This is a matter of personal taste. There are trends. There are many people who loved Philip Seymour Hoffman's acting. But if you don't, you're not wrong. At worst, you're eccentric. (An interesting question—and one you didn't ask so I won't answer it, here—is why are there trends? Even if Philip Seymour Hoffman isn't objectively a great actor, why do so many people love him? For that matter, why do so many people love the Beatles, Shakespeare, and Leonardo Da Vinci? Maybe someone will ask a question about why there are general trends in taste...) I'm a director who has been working with actors for almost 30 years, and I'm the son of a film historian. I'll give you my definition of good acting. But I really want to stress (for the last time, then I'll quit) that if I say Pacino is great and you disagree, my experience does not make me right and you wrong. It just means we have different tastes. For me, an actor is good if ... 1. he makes me believe he's actually going through whatever his character is going through. I'm talking somewhat about physical stuff ("He really is getting shot!" "He really is jumping off a moving train!") but mostly about psychological stuff. ("He really is scared!" "He really is in love!") If an actor seems to be faking it, he's not doing his job. 2. he has surprises me. This is the most nebulous requirement, but it's important. Except for really small parts that aren't supposed to call attention to themselves (e.g. a bank teller who just cashes the hero's checks), it's not enough for actors to just seem real. Seeming real is a requirement, but a second requirement is that I can't predict their every reaction before they have it. Think of how a woman might react if her boyfriend breaks up with her. There are many, many truthful ways—ways which would seem like a human being reacting and not like a space alien behaving in some bizarre, unbelievable way. She might break down and cry; she might laugh hysterically; she might throw water in his face; she might go completely numb, having no expression at all... An actor's job is to know the breadth of human possibility and the depths of his own possibilities. he must pull from this well and surprise us. Otherwise, he becomes boring and predictable. There are many ways an actor can surprise. Gary Oldman and Johnny Depp surprise us by being truthful while playing multiple, very different roles. Jack Nicholson surprises by being ... surprising. Even though he's not a chameleon like Oldman or Depp, you never know what he's going to do next. But whatever he does, it's grounded in psychological reality. It never seems fake. Christopher Walken, Glenn Close, Al Pacino, and many others have a surprising danger to them. They're a little scary to be around, because you feel they might jump you or blow up at you at any moment. They are ticking time bombs. And, of course, many comedic actors (e.g. Julia Louis-Dreyfus) surprise us in all sorts of quirky, zany ways. Or watch Katharine Hepburn and Cary Grant in "Bringing Up Baby." Absolutely surprising and absolutely truthful! Another great example of surprising acting that never seems fake is Diane Keaton's work in "Annie Hall." 3. he is vulnerable. Great actors share the parts of themselves that most people keep hidden. They are always naked. (Some are literally naked, but I'm talking about emotional nakedness.) Bad actors are guarded. They don't want to share the parts of themselves that are ugly, mean, petty, jealous, etc. There are so many examples of actors being naked on stage and screen. My favorite is Rosalind Russell in the movie "Picnic." Rent it some time if you haven't seen it. She plays a middle-aged schoolteacher who is in danger of growing old an dying alone. There's a heartbreaking scene in which she begs a man to marry her. She goes down on her knees in front of him. She gives up every scrap of dignity inside her and lets the scared, hurting parts of herself burst out. These are the same scared, hurt parts that are inside all of us—the parts we work hard to hide. Hiding them (by holding them in) takes a toll on us, and one of the greatest gifts actors can give is the sacrifice of their dignity. They expose themselves so that we don't have to. They are like Christ dying for our sins. This ties in with everything I wrote above: when actors are exposed and raw, it's always surprising. And if it doesn't seem real, there's no point to it. In fact, this sort of emotional nakedness is very hard to fake. If you ever get a sense that an actor is showing you a secret part of himself, he probably is. Examples (in my opinion) are Julianne Moore and Bryan Cranston. Also, rent "The Browning Version" sometime. The early one (not the remake). Watch Michael Redgrave. He turns himself inside out and wrings out all his pain. 4. he knows how to listen. It's fascinating to watch actors when they're not speaking. Some are too caught up in ego or technicalities (e.g. trying to remember their next line) to totally focus on whoever it is they're acting with. Others seem to register everything they hear. You can see whatever is being said to them physically affecting them, as if the words are slapping them across the face. Watch Claire Danes. She's an amazing listener. 5. he has a well-honed "instrument." By which I mean he knows how to use his voice and body to serve whatever role he's playing. This doesn't necessarily mean he's slim and has a six-pack. James Gandolfini used his body well. It means he knows how to move and talk in expressive ways. His voice and body aren't fighting him or holding tension that's inappropriate to his role. One negative example: Kristen Stewart. I find it almost painful to watch her. She looks like she'd rather be anywhere else besides in front of a camera. She is (or seems) very self-conscious. To me, Hoffman was great because he embodied all of these traits. He was vocally and physically gifted. He wasn't in great shape, but he used the shape he had in expressive ways. If you watch him closely when he's not speaking, you'll see he always listened to his co-stars closely. What they said affected him deeply, and his reactions grew organically our of whatever they had previously said or done to him. He was profoundly vulnerable. Always. This was his most distinctive trait. You always knew what you were getting from him was raw and honest. It was this rawness—as well as intelligence and a sly sense of humor—that made his work surprising and fresh. And I never once saw anything from him that seemed fake. I don't hate Tom Cruise the way some people do. To me, he's believable most of the time. He's just not very interesting. He rarely surprises me, and he doesn't seem to dig deep into anything raw or vulnerable inside him. He seems guarded. The must vulnerable I've seen him is in "Eyes Wide Shut," in which he did some good work. But it wasn't brilliant. And it's not his norm. Keep in mind that many people (who aren't themselves actors, directors, or obsessive film buffs) aren't very clear on what an actors contributes to a film. Which is fine. It's not necessary for most audiences members to understand who does what during production. Lots of people think an actor is great if they like his character. But that's often a function of good writing more that good acting. Or they think he's good if he pulls off some impressive effect, such as gaining or losing a lot of weight or pretending to be handicapped. Those are impressive stunts, but they aren't the core of what actors do. If you forced me to rank Dustin Hoffman in "Rain Man" vs. Dustin Hoffman in "Kramer vs. Kramer," I'd say he did more exciting work in the latter. In "Rain Man" he was able to hid behind some stunts. In "Kramer vs. Kramer," he just had to be truthful. Some people think acting is good if they like the movie. Keanu Reeves, in my mind, is a horrible actor—mostly because he's wooden and fake. It often seems as if he's reading from cue cards rather than saying words that are his. But some people like him because they think the Matrix films are cool. They confuse the movies with the actor. If some other actor had been in those films, those same people would have liked him. It's not really the actor (or not entirely the actor) they're liking. But since he plays the protagonist, they focus on him. Finally, many people confuse an actor's life with his work. Tom Cruise is a good example. He's a high-profile Scientologist, and many people dislike that religion. They dislike his acting at least in part because they find him unsavory as a person. To some extent, this may be a sign of bad acting on his part. At least, he's not a good-enough actor to make people forget about his private life while they're watching him in movies. To some extent, it wouldn't matter how skilled he was. Currently, many people are having strong reactions to work by Woody Allen and Mia Farrow that have nothing to do with what they're doing on screen. I'm not even remotely saying such people are wrong, stupid, or crazy. I'm just saying that people's reactions to actors are often complicated and not 100% influenced by performances. UPDATE: a couple of people have asked me to elaborate on my claims about Keanu Reeves. They feel that although he's often wooden, this is appropriate for his character in "The Matrix." I will admit up front that I only saw the film once, when it first came out, so it's possible I'm misremembering. Certainly, a good director can sometimes put bad actors to good use. Let me confine my remarks about Keanu to his acting in general, not just in "The Matrix," though I am still skeptical about his work in that movie. There is a difference between playing an undemonstrative person and being a wooden actor. In fact, playing someone who is reserved is very difficult (because you have to act without showing very much), and the actors who pull it off are brilliant. I would point you towards Anthony Hopkins in "Remains of the Day," Tommy Lee Jones in many of his roles, and even Clint Eastwood in "Dirty Harry." Those actors manage to convey the sense that, though they have stony exteriors, there's much going on underneath. To me, Keanu Reeves conveys an actor who is showing up and saying his lines. I don't believe much else is going on underneath except maybe nervousness. If you feel otherwise, that's fine. Remember, it's subjective. Having auditioned many actors, I'm used to hearing ones that can take any writer's lines and make it sound like their own words. And I'm also used to less experienced (or less gifted) ones who sound uncomfortable with words that aren't their own. They sounds as if they're are reciting or reading something. They sounds scripted. Listen to Keanu in the clip, below, especially at around 10-seconds in, when he says, "I have offended you with my ignorance, Count." Many of his line-readings sound like that to me. He has not fully lifted them off the page and into his own mind and body.  I don't know if you can see a difference between Keanu, above, and Tommy Lee Jones, below. They are both pretty deadpan. The difference, for me, is that Jones seems to be speaking his own words, even though they are just as scripted as the ones Reeves speaks. Jones is just much more comfortable in his skin and much more able to "own" his lines.

This is just an opinion, don't shoot me. Arguably you can tell if someone is a bad actor by asking if they ever go to the corner store to buy toilet roll and milk by themself, or do they have staff to do that? If you cannot create an anonymous regular personality to do everyday normal stuff without being swarmed then your real life personality is too close to the characters you put on the screen. There's a story that Jennifer Aniston was once in a famous department store and a sales assistant quietly told her the Rachel Look was so last year. Funny. There's another story that British TV and Radio personality Chris Tarrant came third in a Chris Tarrant lookalike contest. So this isn't really all that hard. People are naturally disposed to assume that you merely look like someone famous. But still, some celebrities complain they can't walk around like normal people. It's because they suck at acting. The next thing to look at is chemistry on the screen. When you look at Alan Rickman opposite Bruce Willis in Die Hard, they matched each other's rhythms, tones, pacing and style very well. I don't rate Bruce Willis as a great actor, he always seems to be Bruce Willis in everything, but he had a natural rhythm about him that Alan was able to work with. Of course Alan Rickman was one of the greatest British actors to have ever lived. In Robin Hood Prince of thieves they had to edit out a lot of his stuff against Kevin Costner as he “…acted the other guy off the screen” (exact quote). So that's a failure on both sides. Alan Rickman and Kevin Costner just didn't have the on screen zing. The oomph. The magic. A really good actor creates chemistry on screen. So we've looked at how an actor is when off duty being a civilian. We've looked at the idea of how they work with other people. Next we can look at their ability to take direction. Hollywood is full of big names that many directors don't want to work with. The bubble has burst on the idea that a huge name pulls in the crowd. It really doesn't. A good Director knows how to press someone's buttons to get the right emotional responses, but a good Actor listens and gets the scene done in fewer than 12 takes. I admire Jennifer Lawrence. Her Katniss Everdeen character was significantly different to the chick stuck on a space ship or the 1970s New York wife of a grifter. But I have heard she listens and does as she is asked and nails the scene fairly quickly. You can argue she will not have the longevity of Meryl Streep or Helen Mirren but actually she really might. Why? Because she isn't just eye candy on a screen. She looks for interesting women she can play and have fun with the roles. So those are my thoughts. Good acting relies on not just being Joe or Jane Bloggs, movie star. But actually being someone else that you have never seen before and don't recognise the actor until half way into the film if you are lucky. Good acting relies on chemistry with your Co stars. Whether it's a shitty daytime soap or a movie that took four years in the making. If you cannot get that spark with the rest of the cast then it's a straight to DVD nightmare to forget ever existed. Good acting relies on taking direction. A good Director has a clear vision and communicates that. A good Actor or Actress listens and then performs.

I think Marcus Geduld is right on the money in talking about how we judge the results of performers. However, I’ll offer what I think is another tack in answering this question: I think it’s also possible to talk a bit about how a performance is crafted and observe things which are well-crafted. One can talk about these things separately from whether or not the acting is good or bad in the sense of liking/not liking or believing/not believing. One can also look at the situation of a performance, and try to discern how an actor is using the resources of the script, the medium and his/her own abilities. This tack, to me, is just that: it’s not staking out an objective standard, it’s just another way of locating performances on the map of good and bad. For example, Kenneth Branagh doing, “Oh what a rogue and peasant slave am I” from the version of Hamlet that he directed is an example of good acting, whether or not you are partial to the result. One respect in which it is good is how he takes theatrical material and crafts his performance so that it is both theatrical and cinematic simultaneously. Much of what he does physically, could be done on a stage - that is to say, the scale of his movement would be visible to a theatre audience. What he does vocally explores the full range of what a voice can do in terms of volume - from whispers, that could only be audible in a performance for the camera, to shouting at the top of his lungs. That this is all co-ordinated with the movement of the camera is also well-calibrated - Branagh takes full advantage of doing this in one fluid movement of the camera rather than using cuts to vary the scale of his performance, from intimate to bombastic and then back down to the intimate. Then there is what he is doing with his speech: It’s crystal clear. He not only delivers every sound, but also every caesura…I get the impression that we’re watching somebody very smart think aloud. Now…someone could say: Well, that’s all “interesting”, or “accurate”, or “very well observed, Spencer”; But I still don’t like it. I didn’t think that was good, or I don’t believe this or that about the performance. However, I think you would be at pains to say, from the standpoint of craft, that that was “bad acting”. And, who knows? Maybe 10–20 years from now, that performance will look mannered and stale, because of what Marcus Geduld noted about trends. In which case, it might simply be dismissed as bad - but that conclusion would only be one possible end point to the conversation to be had with regard to good and bad. If you look at Olivier’s film version of Hamlet, say, it’s not going to hit you the same way it hit his audience, and, personally, it doesn’t really grab me. But I’d be a bit of a fool to say it’s bad. I think most people would be left unmoved by it today. That still wouldn’t make it bad. Someone in 2018 not likely going to be grabbed by his performance, unless that someone has a very expansive experience of the acting at his time, and knowledge of the limits of the cinema at his time, or is sensitive enough to imagine something on a big screen, while watching it on something small….or, unless that someone is just a poetic soul who can intuitively connect with stuff across boundaries of style, medium and taste. Good and bad is partly what the actors and their collaborators bring, and partly, it’s what any given someone brings to watching it. ****In a similar vein, if you want to see okay-to-meh acting vs. very good acting, look at Neo and the Oracle in the first installment of The Matrix. Keeanu Reeves in this scene is stolid, slightly stiff, and it fits the scene and the world, but I am not totally sold on what he actually does…but, also, it’s harder to judge because this scene has cuts, and I can’t see what he’s doing when the camera is on the Oracle. A lot of good acting has to do with what you’re doing when the focus is not on you - and you can’t see this in a scene with cuts. However, there is one little thing I can put a finger on in Reeves’ performance - his reaction to the Oracle’s line: “And don’t worry about the vase”. I think an actor with a stronger sense of crafting slapstick (or with better direction), would have knocked over the vase without stealing a look in the same direction that the vase is. Reeves does this awkward take to a wall, with no shelf, that’s just two feet away, just above the vase that he’s knocking over… so you can see he’s doing this contrived pretense of not really noticing the vase, but still managing to knock it over. And why is he turning his head so quickly? It’s a vase that the Oracle mentioned-it’s not going to be flying at his head like a projectile. It’s okay or ignorable the first time you see it, because it happens quickly; you might not process these details consciously…I know I didn’t. But I still think an audience-brain catches that stuff, because I still remember that my first impression of Gloria Foster’s performance is that it was priceless and that Reeves was a bit flat. And I still think this upon repeated viewings. By contrast, Gloria Foster is completely unhurried in everything she does - which is remarkable given the amount of money that every take of these big budget movies costs, the number of people waiting around to get to the next shot, just off camera, etc. And a lovely note that she hits when she says, “What’s funny(?)” - her line is not inflected as a question. She delivers it rhetorically. So, is the Oracle covering up a gap in her knowledge? Is the Oracle telling Neo: there’s nothing funny here, so get with the effin program? Is it both? An actor paying less attention to the text, might deliver that line with a rising inflection, rather than as a rhetorical question; and a director concerned with a gazillion other things on a tight schedule might not notice one way or the other; but Foster’s choice of inflection gives the scene an ambiguity and tension that a lesser actor might not have brought to it. Again, you can like it or not, but you can’t say Foster’s performance is not well-crafted and, also, I think it can be favorably compared to Reeves’ performance.

Thank you for your A2A, Alex C. Lee! I was puzzled by this question a lot as a little kid. I often heard about how Heath Ledger was so great as the Joker in The Dark Knight, or how Kevin Spacey was a great actor as well as Lester Burnham in American Beauty. How could two vastly different performances both be considered “great”? Well, as I’ve started making my own short films and understanding the process of filmmaking, the difficulties of acting also demonstrate what makes a good actor or a bad one. As audiences we don’t see the hours of waiting that actors have to endure, as well as the multiple takes actors have to do for scenes. As acting has become more and more method in practice, there is also the daunting task of acting like another person at certain times, doing things such as crying on command, which I cannot yet do on camera. From my experience, I believe there are two sides to good and bad acting: behind and in front of the camera. Behind the camera, good actors are easy to work with. They always show up on time, remember their lines, and follow direction easily. They have a thick skin, treat the crew with kindness and respect, and don’t screw up every take. With a strong director and a strong script, inexperienced actors that can work well with others can give great performances. In front of the camera, good actors are dedicated to their craft. They perform scenes consistently over 50 takes, they can wait for 12 hours in a trailer then show up to a take where they’re supposed to mourn over the death of an old friend and nail it. When they act, they don’t read lines off of a page, they convince you that they are someone else. Bear in mind that these aren’t set in stone at all nor are they mutually exclusive or inclusive. In my opinion, there are few truly bad actors; many performances are sabotaged with poor editing, terrible direction, or a weak story. If you look at a movie like Samurai Cop, the actors’ performances are dreadful because the director was a foreigner who wrote a weak script and only did one take of each scene with horrible direction. If you look at the Star Wars prequels, the actors feel stiff and half-asleep because they can’t see where they are (given all the green screens) and they were given an overly-dramatic script. If you’re still having trouble understanding a good or a bad actor, my best advice is to simply watch a lot of really terrible movies. Watch movies where actors don’t know how to walk. They walk too fast, too slowly, too upright, like in Birdemic: Shock and Terror. You can see scenes where someone dies and their reaction is completely off like in Abar, The First Black Superman. Movies where the actor speaks too quickly and is unintelligible like Plan Nine from Outer Space, or where someone is burning the lens after every take like in anything made by Neil Breen. When you see those lackluster performances, or your own like I have, it’s much easier to see how good actors function, because like professional athletes, it’s hard to see how great something is until you have something to compare it to.  Written in eighteen minutes while listening to So What’cha Want by the Beastie Boys.

Well, Anyone can easily differentiate between good, bad, great and worst acting. If one has a good taste of cinema, he/she can easily figure out the quality of acting. I'll give some examples based on good and bad acting. Crying How a bad actor cries  How a good actor cries  Breaking down How a bad actor breaks down     How a good actor breaks down      How a bad actor smiles  How a good actor smiles   How a bad actor gets surprised  How a good actor gets surprised  How a bad actor gets angry   How a good actor gets angry   How a bad actor gets scared   How a good actor gets scared   Look at her,  Look at her facial expression, look at her eyes. She is crying. Does she look fake? Nope. Because she is expressing her emotions through her eyes. We can easily see her pain in her eyes and even in her skin. She isn't overacting or making weird faces in order to express her pain. Just simply natural. Because when we feel pain, our eyes simply reflect it. We don't have to try too hard to show that we're in pain. So, It's all about believable expressions  A good actor - A good actor is one who can express his emotions through his eyes. One who acts but doesn't look like he's acting. One who can make us believe in his/her character. One who doesn't try too hard to make audience emotional. One who lives in the character. One who is versatile. One whose dialogue delivery is as powerful as fire. One who can change his/her facial expressions and body language within seconds (as required). One who steals the show and has a great screen presence. One who plays challenging roles and make them look real and easy. One who has the knowledge of a good script. One who interacts, connects and relates with the audiences through his expressions more than the dialogues. And there are many actors whose acting abilities are exceptional. They even make us believe in angels and vampires. Natural actor is what we call a good or even a great actor. A bad actor - A bad actor is one who can't act. One who is unable to express his feelings through his eyes and body language. One who makes acting look like acting. One who overacts and makes us cringe out loud. One whose facial expressions don't match with the situation. They make everything look fake, cheesy and kinda funny. They try to hide their bad acting skills with heavy clichéd dialogues and action. They make real things look unreal. When they cry, it looks like they're laughing. When they laugh, it looks like they're crying. When they're excited, it looks like they're gonna slash someone, when they make love, they look like perverts. There's no depth in their actions. They have same facial expressions all the time because that's what they are best in. It is because acting is not their cup of tea. So they put more effort into their acting, they try too hard just to come up as the below average actors. They are scared of real good scripts and challenging roles. So they never sign those films which have unique concepts and great productions. And they end up in doing mindless crappy movies where the acting is not that much required. And if you're an Indian, you know whom I am talking about. These ‘bad actors’ must seriously join the acting schools. A good actor is never afraid of taking risks and portraying the unconventional roles on the screen. They dare to take challenges and can do much more than what they're expected to do. Some movies even break all the social norms and stereotypes. Mass audiences can't get these types of movies because they are used to ordinary ‘masala movies' that are made only for entertainment. So the good films with good acting and good storyline often fail to make an impact at the box office. However, they also make us realize that good actors and good movies still exist.  The really good actors aren't afraid to get out of their comfort zone and always want to try something new. They are so passionate about their characters that they don't give damn about their looks and appearances. They just give their 100% and win the hearts of their fans, audiences (who have great cinematic taste) and critics. And that is what we call ‘good acting' and a ‘good actor'. Hope you enjoyed :) - Thankyou

It can be very subjective, but sometimes acting expressivity... the perception of an acting performance... may be affected by directing and editing.  A director may not prominently highlight an actor's more effective, powerful moments.  Their performance may seem resultingly understated and even lackluster. Also, if an editor decides to hide the facial expression of an actor portraying a man, breaking down upon learning of tragedy, opting for a different visual, you can't be very impressed by that acting performance.  Also, there's the Kuleshov Effect, where an editor can show an expressionless face... let's say your face as you're reading from the screen... and then a bowl of soup.  Then your face again.  You'd look hungry.  What great acting!  (not really by your doing)  So sometimes people can read too much into their perception of a performance when rating an actor's ability.  Certainly on the internet, "everybody's got an opinion".  They'll reach for whatever opinion they can formulate, sometimes not being able to peel away the layers and realize what exactly an actor was responsible for. But I'd like to answer your question, while I'm at it :)  Horrible acting can be experienced by asking your non-actor friends to read some random dialogue in a scene with any emotion.  They might have some natural ability, but even then, it's probably not going to be pretty.  Compare how they sound to people talking naturally... try eavesdropping on a conversation in a restaurant.  Your non-actor buddies are going to sound like they're reading, not talking on their own.  It's a different part of the brain.  There's no emotion.  They might try to raise and lower their voices at certain parts, and if they're cute, maybe even mimic voices, but it won't sound anywhere as believable as that restaurant conversation. What makes good acting?  I see the best results when actors are reacting naturally to imagined circumstances.  It's about putting your mindset into another world, and actually learning to think like another person.  You can imagine why exactly Heath Ledger was so screwed up after his relentless preparation to play this character:   What drives a person to become this?  What can possibly be going through the mind of the Joker at this moment, and more importantly, why?  Heath prepared himself to not just pretend to be the Joker for his final performance... but he invented a way, including a backstory, personality, and real world situation, where, while delivering his lines, he WAS the Joker.  Everything he said, and did (body language/facial expressions) were completely motivated by his recreation of the mind... of the Joker. According to the NY Daily News, Ledger told reporters he "slept an average of two hours a night" while playing "a psychopathic, mass-murdering, schizophrenic clown with zero empathy ..." He added: "I couldn't stop thinking. My body was exhausted, and my mind was still going." Some believed it was this role that led to Heath Ledger's drug-related death. This is an extreme case, but it shows what acting is all about.  Vulnerability is a key factor.  An actor must drop their guard and not try to "look a certain way".  They must let their new personality take over, for all to see.  If they retain even the slightest control, or their mindset is not convincing enough for them to retain, the believability falls apart, and genuine emotion is lost. Acting is difficult.  Just trying to force yourself to cry realistically, without an onion on a cutting board, should convince you of that.  Try to act genuinely frightened.  Can you imagine yourself at the top of a ski slope, knowing you're rather safe on a bunny slope, but being paralyzed with fear to budge?  Can you actually FEEL that fear in an audition room?  It ain't easy to do. An "actor's director" gives their actors a plethora of details on the backstory, and the false world that the actor must enter.  What holes are left, an actor must fill through their own character analysis.  They must draw on their own experiences that inspire the emotions they must feel.  If the actor has never been on a ski slope, perhaps they must imagine at the bottom of the slope is the neighbor's pitbull with gnashing teeth.  Whatever must be invented should feel like a schizophrenic illusion. If you want to see bad acting, try looking at the PhD movie, Piled Higher and Deeper Movie.  They sadly ruined a great idea by having actual PhD's act in the movie.  You'll see quite plainly what I'm referring to when I describe very fake-sounding dialogue.  None of them are trained actors, and although the rest of the production seems good, the acting keeps the viewers from "suspending their disbelief".  You can't just pay attention to what's going on in the movie.  You're always thinking, "Here are these PhD students being silly in a movie." If you want to see good acting, well, there are a ton of great examples, like Heath Ledger's.  I'd like to draw attention to the acting, however, in Alexander Payne's movies.  Especially with the latest film of his I've seen, Nebraska, I've become extremely impressed with how natural his acting performances are.  A good litmus test is how he does not dress up his scenes with continuous action or dialogue.  Often, he embraces silence.  There are scenes in that movie such as this one:    Ever sit with your family and you just don't have much to say?  There are long pauses of silence, where this family is just watching TV, with awkward silence.  The sparse words that are delivered are perfectly chosen and entertaining, but otherwise, this movie is the stark reality of real life.  But I found myself interested, amused, happy and sad, throughout this movie.  Alexander Payne and his actors were brilliant. More well-known, along similar lines, is Sideways, also directed by Payne.  Again, natural moments blanketed with silence:   Without great acting, Alexander Payne's movies would not be possible. Peter Jackson's movies?   Well, good acting is more of a "nice to have" :) If you’re interested in browsing some of my other answers related to filmmaking, check out my blog, Director's Notes

BAD ACTING Any person can do realistic acting. Realistic acting with lack of conviction and commitment is bad acting. How does one know it is bad? Because it is almost like mimicry and is overdramatic and does not have continuity. The actor breaks character very often because he is not the character at all, he is just acting like the character. Before the actors used to speak in the Transatlantic accent in movies to show class and style but that was not the way ordinary people of America talked. That is bad acting for that deviates from the truth of our society and people being portrayed. GOOD ACTING But good acting is different. I, personally admire the teachings of Stella Adler, who revolutionized acting from dramatic show of emotions to the process of actually becoming the character. Method acting is good acting. Marlon Brando is considered the first person to do truthful acting by becoming the character. Acting is lying for a living but even in that lie there should be truth and finding that truth is the actor’s job.  To recognize good acting, one must know the process. The following are my steps to becoming the character: Step 1: Observe the character: Say the character is Abraham Lincoln. Now, to portray Lincoln, you would have to first observe him. Look at his pictures for hours. Read all of his books. Explore his thoughts and feelings. Understand his philosophy of life. Step 2: Sympathy: Next you must be able be sympathetic towards the character. Understand the circumstances he has been in, the struggles he has went through. Step 3: Empathy: Now, you must be able to relate to the character. For that you need to be a little sensitive. To feel what the character felt, you must push yourself into the circumstances that he faced in his life. Step 4: Become the character: Suspend from your reality and be truthful to your imagination. Now, you must full commit to becoming Lincoln. Don’t remember emotions, remember circumstances and be truthful to that circumstance. Then emotions will come out, automatically. THE RESULT: Daniel Day Lewis portrayed Lincoln and won an Oscar for his performance. Even between shots and throughout the film, he was always in character. He was always referred to as Lincoln and he was always living at that particular time and under those circumstances that Lincoln lived in. THAT IS GOOD ACTING. His accent, the way he walks, the way he reacts and the way he feels inside is not his. It is Lincoln’s. There is no break in character and there is no fake display of emotions, it is truthful and moving. Then on the big screen, we see a Daniel Day Lewis portray Lincoln without any mimicry or overdramatic gestures. We see him become Lincoln. We seem him as thoughtful, courageous, brave and kind as Lincoln. We see his dilemmas, his moments of greatness. The way he talks and walks in Lincoln is different from the way he talks and walks in real life and in other movies but throughout the film, he walks that way because he is Lincoln.  “So we all act -- just some people get paid for it." -Marlon BrandoWithout practice, this is just theory. So, to learn and understand good acting, join theatre and practice everyday. Only then you will be able to do the job of a true actor or at least understand the difference between a method actor and a person who displays fake emotions without feeling anything in unreal circumstances.

A lot of very good stuff in this post.  I'd like to add this: a good actor believes in his character, a great actor has his audience believing in his character. Someone once said that "music is what happens between the notes".  I would say that acting is what happens between the lines and the movement. For me there is nothing, absolutely nothing like the electricity you can feel in the air between the line, and the reaction to the line.  As an actor, you say or do something, and there's this moment where there's a perceivable pressure in the air that breaks into a laugh, or best of all, a gasp. When you can do that, and you can do it night after night, or character after character, that's when you begin to be a good actor. It differs from actor to actor, and also in one time to another time.  What worked for the great actors of the past - like Spencer Tracy, Laurence Olivier, Katherine Hepburn, etc. won't work for actors today, but actors today can bring performances that have no less impact. An actor knows more than just the lines, he or she understands the character, and can bring elements of the current time and their culture into a performance that their contemporary audience can understand. Sometimes a performance can be so universal it transcends time.  I recently played the ghost of John Barrymore in the comedy "I Hate Hamlet."  I studied some of Barrymore's old films, and I watched the silent film "The Beloved Rogue" (1927). Barrymore's depiction of a man exiled from a city he loves reaches across time.  He starts the scene dressed as a clown, celebrating All Fools Day.  He offends a nobleman, and the king sentences him to exile. As he strips off his makeup, in two and a half minutes we see him lose his joy, and his tragic face is revealed.  (You can see it here - start at 22:00 minutes - runs to about 24:40):    Filmed almost 90 years ago, no lines, no sound, no special effects, yet it's as moving as any drama you'll see today. What's the difference between good and bad acting?  In bad acting, the audience sees movement and hear lines.  In good acting, they see and hear truth.

( After re-reading my response, Ive realized I wrote more than I intended to. As usual I summed up my answer in a TL;DR cliff notes list at the bottom of the page. ) There isn't really one certain way to define a good performance. In the end, acting is largely subjective, and there are great actors, bad actors, good actors, terrible actors, amazing, incompetent and every where in between. And just because someone's a great actor, doesn't mean they always give a good performance. Another important aspect to this discussion is different types of acting. Some actors are better at dialogue, some are better at being physical, some better at telling or being sad. Some are better being action stars and some are better as a stars of a deep psychological thriller.    So what separates a good actor from a great actor in my opinion, is something called their acting range. Acting range is simply the variety (or range) of different roles a certain actor is able to portray, and obviously how well he portrays them.  Such is why actor Leonardo DiCaprio is (rightfully so) considered one of the best actors around. He has done different accents with perfection (Wolf of Wall Street, Django Unchained), carried entire movies with very little dialogue (The Revenant), played everything from scared yet adventurous kid falling in love (Titanic, even Romeo + Juliet), a despicable asshole (Django Unchained), a likable hero (too many to name).  Range is what separates actors like Tom Cruise (a good actor, very good action star, but not on the level of DiCaprio and others) from the big boys. Another way acting can often be influenced is method acting. How far did the actor go to truly transform into his character? Christian Bale is right up there with Leo as far as the best method actors of our time goes (Bale has great range as well, see the Dark Knight trilogy compared to American Psycho or The Fighter).  As far as how I (and most) judge a single performance in movies or TV, are based on a few things:  Range inside the Performance: The best performances are those that vary between hot headed and cool, angry and sad, characters at their best and at their worst. Anything besides this is often characterized as         one-dimensional. However this isn't to say good performances can't exist that don't go hot to cold, such as Jon Hamm in Mad Men. Consistency: This may seem like a contradiction to point 1, but it really just means that they're playing the same character throughout the movie. However, it also means that character can of course change throughout the film, which what's called development or progression. Believability: Lastly and perhaps most importantly, the actor's first job in a role is to entirely immerse  the audience in the experience. If you can't do that, the entire movie flops. It's hard to become invested in a story that not even the characters or actors believe in. That at pretty much sums it up, I may edit the answer later and add in a list of great performances. If you really want examples, look at the Acadamy Awards' winners and nominees for Best Actor, Actress, Supporting Actor and  Supporting Actress. Despite the recent controversy, they still pick amazing performances each year. TL;DR -  Acting range is very important. Every actor has hits and misses. Believability, Consistency and Acting Range define performances. For examples see anything nominated by major tv and movie awards shows Thanks for reading, and feel free to follow for more :)

Do you find this image creepy enough? How will you feel if you get locked in a house with this person? No telephones. No internet. Nobody else. Just you and him. This is called as good acting and Jack Nicholson did a good job. The character Jack Torrance in the movie The Shining will not scare you off like some cheap jump-scare because deep inside you are sure that he is definitely going to do something nasty. He’s a recovering alcoholic and has injured Danny previously which you know at the start of story itself. The director Stanley Kubrick has prepared you to get frightened. And it’s not a popcorn horror flick. It’s a psychological thriller…remember that. Jack psychologically disturbs you. He’s the one who pushes the story forward. The more he loses sanity, the more the story intensifies. You may predict the end because of antagonistic features of Jack. The question is not of what will happen. It’s the ‘how’ which engages the audience. The actor executes the screenplay with utmost care. Not only that, he contributes a certain level of value to movie by his improvisation. That’s what makes it a thrilling experience to watch. Can you tell me what you understand from these pictures?     You can see such repetitive expressions, nuances, diction and mannerisms in the whole movie. And she is the protagonist of the movie! The story is basically about a vampire falling in love with a human. The lead character Bella Swan (Kristen Stewart) in Twilight is not pushing the story forward. The story lets you predict the future. So should we made interested in the ‘how’ part? No. The character does not delve deeper. It can’t engage you. It can’t react or respond on the top of everything. Because most of the times character seems confused. Not because of the dilemma between Vampire and Werewolf but because it cannot comprehend to audience of what’s going on. So at least…it should be a nice popcorn flick, right? Nope. The character doesn’t entertain you too. Why? Was the screenplay responsible? Maybe. But as Stanley Kubrick has stated: “A screenplay is not meant to be read. It’s to be realized on film.” (Source of Quote: Stanley Kubrick: A Biography (1997) written by Vincent LoBrutto). The screenplay of Twilight is not realized on-screen. The lead actor doesn’t try to keep the audience interested and rather shifts the burden on the synopsis which most of the audience knows. The actors (including Stewart) don’t contribute any value and expect the moviegoers to come after doing the homework of reading the novel/Wikipedia. This is….well… not-good acting. I will like to give more examples of good acting though. Amjad Khan as Gabbar Singh in Sholay Amjad Khan was the epicenter of the whole movie. And it is a fact that Sholay wouldn’t have been successful without this guy in it. His purpose is to make you afraid. And he does. Unlike the typical villains in Bollywood movies, he played the role quite uniquely but keeping the crux intact. He affects the movie both in presence and absence. Everyone is happy in the village until he enters the scene. His introduction in the story not only makes the atmosphere serious but also intensifies the rather slow pace of movie. The backstory of Gabbar Singh’s power and influence keeps his fear even in his absence. But we would have thought it like some joke if he hadn’t showed that on-screen. And he’s damn good in proving us the brutal honesty of screenplay mixed with fear of Gabbar Singh among the villagers. The dialogues written by the Salim-Javed screenwriting duo surely make the film colorful and entertaining. But how the actor delivers the dialogue is also of much importance. And Amjad Khan does that beautifully. All his dialogues of Sholay still echo in our ears. I really think that Amitabh Bachchan’s Angry Young Man character was very natural to him because of his heroic persona in those years so it was not as risky feat as of Amjad Khan's role. During that time, actors had fear of getting typecast as villain. So Amjad Khan’s accepting of a negative role and even performing it so well that he carved a niche in Indian cinema (and Internationally too) is certainly what intrigues me. Nawazuddin Siddiqui as IPS Jaideep Ambalal Majmudar in Raees I think the whole burden of showing acting range was on him. He is actually a positive character. So he has no darker shades in character sketch. Which makes it harder to engage the audience. But he does engage us and proves that actor can do anything. Given the movie record of past five years of Shah Rukh Khan, today he is more of a commercial actor than a critically acclaimed. So the jobs of Khan and Siddiqui are pre-decided. The job of Khan was to bring heroic presence and concentrate less on acting. So acting opportunity is given more to Siddiqui. He plays the good cop. But he’s the one who takes the story forward. Without him in the movie, Raees the character was happily doing his illegal business and there was no need for action. So the movie ends with the death of Raees and vision of IPS Majumdar is completed which was to end the crime taking place because of Raees. So the genre becomes crime action because of Siddiqui’s character. There are millions of examples to prove good acting. Take away the qualities I mentioned, you’ll find bad acting. Note: The Shining is R-rated movie. The minors are not recommended to watch this movie. It is a disturbing movie. Image Sources: (1) Here (2)Here (3) Here (4) Here (5) Here (6) Here (7) Here (8)Here

Hi there, and thanks for the A2A! Theater, acting, drama…these are all subjectively enjoyed by the audience. I can’t speak for anyone else, but here’s what I see when I’m looking at good acting, which isn’t true when there’s acting I think is bad: You forget it’s (celebrity name) you’re seeing. Many times when we see a film, we won’t see an astronaut, we’ll see Matt Damon pretending to be an astronaut, and we agree to overlook this with a wink in the name of our overall enjoyment. Other times, in the beginning of the film you will know from the opening credits that it’s Alan Rickman as Severus Snape, but by the end of the film, you’ve forgotten all about Alan Rickman because Snape is such a real character, with its own life. (I’m really wondering which way I’ll go with Tom Hanks as Mr. Rogers, since I’m from Pittsburgh and grew up with Mr. Rogers on TV and in my city.) You feel real emotions as a result of the performance. Whether that’s laughter, tears, fear…if an actor’s performance is such that it can cause you to suspend your disbelief enough to have emotions caused by something the character is experiencing. My most recent experience of this was Jared Harris’ performance in Chernobyl, and Helena Bonham Carter in the final season 3 episode of The Crown. (With bad acting, I might laugh at a time when the movie clearly doesn’t want you to.) The other actors believe in the performance enough that there is chemistry between them. This can mean believable romantic chemistry like Bradley Cooper and Lady Gaga, or just the belief that these characters really are friends on a soul level (see Azirophale and Crowley in Good Omens; some people think that counts as a romantic relationship…that’s not my personal interpretation but it’s a valid one.) They can demonstrate emotion without yelling. Is some yelling going to be called for in certain works at certain times? Of course. But there are some actors who believe that yelling their lines is what communicates urgency and earnestness at times when lines don’t need to be yelled. The transformation is physical as well. You might have someone putting on elf ears and a prosthetic nose to change more clearly into their characters, but good actors understand that their characters are going to have different stances and walks and affectations than those they have as a person. For an incredible example of this, see pretty much anything Daniel Day Lewis, Cate Blanchett, James McAvoy, Meryl Streep, or Ben Kingsley has ever done. For a film that’s an excellent example, see Geoffrey Rush in Shine. For “what is bad acting?” I guess, the opposite of these points.

Even if they are hardworking they are unable to mentally transform themselves. They are more conscious of their acting so which makes them unable to respond naturally as their character should have. This also limits their ability to improvise and give something new. They are generally not good at picking best script, they get offers according to their ability. So they end up doing same formula movies over and over again. You can intellectually approve their acting, but it will still feel like acting. They are unable to engage you. You can find their movies entertaining in first watch, starts looking boring and stupid in after watching again. They just give you time pass entertainment most of the time. Script and character does not have any depth. Movie easily gets dated after few years. Remain popular only among their fans. Good Actors Are passionate about their acting, they always enjoy to play character that are new, challenging and that has lot of depth. They are usually good at picking scripts and characters. They give utmost important to their character, they research, learn new things, go through mental and physical transformation just get deep into the character, they don’t care much about their own personality as long as they get the character right.  They have deep understanding of psyche of character, they let it playout with heart instead of trying to control their acting intellectually. You feel like you are watching real person. response.answer_text: Just as how you differentiate good and bad painting. Any one can draw a scenery like this  but to draw something like this one needs finesse  But there are people who, due to their own visionary retardation might consider a bad painting to actually be good. A similar disposition is true in case of movies. An actor is like a painter, only he uses his body and face as a canvas to express emotions but not without the eyes of a talented director .One of my favourite actor-director duo is Leonardo-di-caprio and the legend Martin Scorsese . Shutter Island is a movie where Martin basically takes us through the life of a mentally disturbed person, from the inside. In one scene Leo kills his mentally unstable wife because she drowned their children and now desperately urges him to set her “free”. Now appreciate the myriad of emotions that leo portrays: 1.He loves his wife 2.He loved his children too 3.He is helplessly and infuriously drawn to pull the trigger on his wife because she killed their children. Sample the drama and gauge the emotional deepness for yourselves:  The deepness with which leo submerges himself into a character is phenomenal. Sample this clip from “Django Unchained” in which he accidentally smashes his hand on a glass and cuts himself.He improvises the scene using that pain to fuel his hatred even more against black people, which is evident when he smears his own blood across the slave lady’s face.  In his another flick “The revenant” the bear scene is one that gives the chills every time. Now you and me see the bear, but all he saw was a stuntman called Glenn Ennis. So he has to imagine being mauled by a bear. So now you know that the “chills” are not coming from the VFX team alone!  Being a Martin scorsese fan and not appreciating Goodfellas is blasphemy. Martin , robert de niro and Joe pesci are the perfect combination for a great gangster movie which Goodfellas rightfully is. In one scene Joe Pesci gets insulted by a man at a bar counter (Frank Vincent). Now after getting triggered Joe infuriously leaves the scene .Watch how de niro says “okay” to frank when he disagrees that he didn't insult Joe. That “okay” meant “buddy , pretty soon you're going to get your ass handed to you” which he unfortunately gets . This art of expressing a lot more with subtler but strong emotions is an adornment of a good actor. Caveat : the clip contains strong language.  Finally there are artists who draw paintings or emotions not because they love their job but because of money. Such people are found dime a dozen and don't bring any value to their onscreen imagery. One such person is this guy  The reason why his films touch 100 cr plus category is not because he is a good actor but because majority of this country's population hasn't got the maturity to sample something good, they are just like simpletons who after toiling hard all day settle down for whatever food is in front of them. They connect with the stars and venerate them using movie as a medium but a more mature crowd considers it the other way around. They connect with the movie by considering actors as a medium and don’t venerate them like they are GODS. In another country most of these so called stars would have been reduced to dust by now.

You certainly can tell the difference between good and bad acting, even without any training or experience yourself… just as you can tell the difference between good and bad playing of the tuba, even if you’ve never touched the instrument in your life. You simply ask yourself: Do I believe what I see the actor doing — either on stage or on film? People will accept a good deal more phoniness on stage because we expect the actor to be a little “bigger” in voice and gesture so they can reach the 100th row. But we typically see hundreds or even thousands of hours of film and television by the time we’re adults, and long before we come of age, we naturally learn to be super-sensitive about what is a believable performance and what is not. The paradox is that drama is “real life with the boring parts taken out.” We expect actors on screen to be much more interesting than real life itself… but we want the actors to sound so naturalistic that it SOUNDS like real life. You see, the illusion is that something very interesting is going on in front of us, but we just happen to be overhearing and viewing it, because of a hidden camera and hidden mike. (And in stage the illusion is that we are sitting behind an invisible “Fourth Wall.”) And, as viewers, we all get upset if this illusion is broken, by actors who don’t sound as real people would sound if the scene were real. The truly great actors — Marlon Brando in particular — are great because they consistently ask themselves: What would I REALLY do if I were in this situation? It’s what Stanislavsky called “the Magic If,” and Brando was one of the masters. Then there are other considerations — considerations that “lay people” take for granted. We want to never be distracted by the actor wandering out of camera view, or the actor not being well-lit, or mumbling their lines so we can’t make out the words exactly (that’s actually a real problem sometimes) and we get upset if the actor doesn’t hit his “marks,” even if you have no idea what “marks” are. At least you know if when you can’t see the actor’s face. These are all the technical considerations that actors must master before it’s even possible for there to be a good performance. All that said, people with training and/or experience in the business are probably even more sensitive, more aware of the difference between truthful and phony acting.

Immersion is one of the pillars of cinema, and from my perspective, of acting as well. Developing and sustaining a degree of immersion in the audience requires all the multifaceted cogs behind the making of a movie to operate in perfect harmony. If one circular peg falls into a square hole, the spell is broken, and our journey into the world of the film comes to a screeching halt. As such, any aspect of the filmmaking process that severs the aforementioned absorption can be deemed ‘bad.’ Usually, it happens when something calls attention to itself, whether it is the editing, the cinematography or indeed, the acting.  Actors are the primary conduits of the vision of the film. They might not be the pilots of the film, but they are the flight attendants; the face of the operation, it is through them we are invited and shepherded along the journey. Therefore, an acting misstep is far easier to spot than say an editing gaffe. It could be something as banal as inconsistent line reading, or the intonation of a particular word; if it breaks the spell, it’s bad. For me, this isn’t limited to “bad” performances alone. Certain over-the-top performances that are largely agreed upon as being good also break the spell – Sean Penn’s “Is that my daughter in there?” sequence from Mystic River comes to mind. However, I don’t subscribe to the notion that acting is good only when it’s invisible, i.e.; you can’t tell the person is acting. It’s a tightrope, certainly, but certain actors have mastered it. They can maintain the spell, even intensify it, while enacting certain sequences that leave you in awe of their sheer grasp of their craft.  Daniel Day-Lewis in There Will Be Blood, Al Pacino in The Godfather Part II, Cate Blanchett in Blue Jasmine (Or Cate Blanchett, period) and several others serve as prominent examples.  Acting isn’t boxing, chess or golf; it is football, baseball or basketball. That is my needlessly convoluted way of saying that acting is a team sport. So much of what makes a performance “good” or “bad” depends on elements outside of the actor’s raw capability – the potency of the script, the capacity of the director, the decisions made by the editor, and a plethora of other considerations. As for what constitutes “good” acting? Of course, that is profoundly subjective, but certain aspects of a performance do stand out to me.  Presence This is as much about authenticity as it is about charisma. ‘Presence’ to me isn’t merely about magnetism. Sure, certain performers shine brighter than a supernova and compel your eyes to be fixated on them at all times – Denzel Washington being perhaps the finest exponent of this quality. He is the most ‘watchable’ actor I’ve ever seen.  But ‘presence’ can be found in dignified silences just as much as bombastic performances. Think of Gary Oldman in Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy, or Maggie Cheung and Tony Leung in In The Mood for Love or Casey Affleck in Manchester By The Sea. Those performances are worlds removed from the “Look, I’m acting!” brand of performances that routinely gather acclaim, but they have just as much presence and gravitas. The four actors mentioned above completely internalise their character’s motivation and they authentically convey those emotions to the audience.  Subtext Good actors can communicate their character’s thought process to the audience. They show us the wheels that are continually in motion within their characters – how they think, how they feel. For me, there are few better examples of this aspect of acting than Al Pacino’s monumental work in the first two Godfather films. Again, this performance is an example of the ‘team sport’ nature of acting.  Everything had to fall into place to make the ‘Diner’ scene in The Godfather work the way it did. We can virtually see a hazy concoction of rage, torment and hesitation raging inside Michael Corleone. Of course, Pacino does much of the heavy lifting, but it is Michael’s spectacularly fleshed out characterisation and the detailed story beats that grant us the ability to delve into his mind and imagine what he might be thinking.  Subtlety This is perhaps the most subjective of the three, but it is also one that is of colossal significance to me. Good actors can convey paragraphs with a raised glance; they can do so much with so little. Of late, Ryan Gosling stands out to me for his capability to be a subdued yet hugely compelling performer.  Even in his ‘stoic’ avatar, there are different pitches. The depth, nuance and variance he brings to three performances that may at first glance appear to have a lot of similarities – Drive, Blade Runner 2049 and First Man – are astounding. I will forever be a proponent of ‘best acting’ over ‘most acting.’ And Gosling has done some of the best acting I’ve seen this past decade, and he has done so with commendable restraint and subtlety.

Correct me if I’m wrong, but what it sounds like you’re saying is that sometimes it feels like all acting looks pretty much the same (except in a few rare cases - more on that later) and you want to know what people are looking at when they say a performance was good (as ultimately you want to know how to give good performances). What I think that this comes down to is knowing how to measure art generally and knowing what to focus on when one is giving a performance. I think that: the quality of art for an individual is the amount that one learns through the course of observing the artwork. For a scene, this means the amount that one learns (i.e. grows, to put it differently) through the course of watching the scene. The best way for us to learn (as an observer) is to watch someone else learn (because we identify with them). As such, the performances of the actors tend to be the most affecting element of any film and the quality of a performance is the extent to which the actor learns (grows) through the course of a performance. As a fun aside: I’m guessing that you were thinking when you asked the question that performances tend to look the same… unless the performances are really obviously bad or on the rare occasion that one sees a moment that hits us on a deep, gut level. Well, I’ve heard Kevin Jackson (one of my teachers, formerly of NIDA) say that all an Oscar-winning performance comes down to is a few of those moments. A recent example of this for me is Brie Larson’s performance in Room. The moments in which we learn the most tend to come to mind quickly and so I’m guessing that most people who have seen the film that are reading this will remember the part I’m talking about when I say that there’s a single moment of that film in which Brie Larson has her child returned to her, screams and the audience of the film breaks down. She’s being restrained by police and she’s attempting to reach her child in the police vehicle after having last seen the child as it was being sent to the outside world in a dangerous plan to free them from years-long confinement. The actors interpretation of the script demonstrated through the act of performing it (i.e. saying words and doing actions) led to profundity. Tears are the common symptom of deep relaxation of the body. They come when we see something new (usually internally, as in, there’s a mental image) and while they themselves are a form of waste they do indicate that a change has occurred: growth has taken place. The release of tension may also be stated as dealing with trauma. As to how great acting takes place: to (roughly) quote Kevin Jackson once more it is when “the script and the actor align so that we view through them the infinite depth of ourselves”. I would further say that by script what Mr. Jackson is referring to is “the writer’s intention”, which itself may be called‘Truth’, which in turn could be considered as ‘God’/’divine power’. So: the supremacy of acting is the unification of man with God (meaning that the goal of acting is to unify oneself with divine power). The closer that one comes to unifying with God during the course of a performance, the greater the performance is. It is worth noting that the greater that one grows i.e. the wiser that one becomes, the faster that one can grow. (The joke is of the man who says “I don’t understand why everyone says toddlers learn quickly. My son and I started tennis lessons at the same time and he’s yet to even pick up the groundstroke.” The learning becomes subtler but it carries greater power.) This is the best reason to grow more: not for material wealth but because it gives one the potential to grow even faster. This also explains why someone may be a great actor but its not interesting watching them until they start doing something. The art of unifying with God is an entire course of study unto itself (one might well be say “well, of course, we call it art!” :P), suffice it to say in terms of acting a few things that might be worth starting with are: (1) Constantly pursue a greater level of understanding of the idea that acting is nothing more than saying the words and doing the things that one has been given to say and do. Mastery of life (and acting) is mastery of the things that take no skill, (2) Understand that the word (i.e. language) is more important than the universe. “First came the world, and the word was with God, and the word was God.” (John 1:1) The single most important element of a performance is the accent that one uses and the development of one’s voice is the development of one’s power as an actor. (3) Thinking about acting in terms of the ‘five fundamental elements’ (Earth, Water, Fire, Wind). At any time during a performance, if one’s focus has left the moment for whatever reason, focus on the action that corresponds to the energy that one is deficient in. Primarily, if one feels reluctant to continue or that one is “over-acting” focus on asking each line of dialogue as a question to oneself (i.e. Wind). If you can convince everyone that you’re a great artist, you’re a great artist. The best way to do that is to not care whether people do or not (which is achieved by endless, diligent practice). It also can help to build a story around a performance which comes from approaching preparation for the role in a novel way.

‘Hera Pheri’ (Chicanery) is one of my all-time favourite movies. I have seen it multiple times and every time I see it, I can’t help but notice one small scene that, for me, differentiates good and bad acting. The scene is when Khadak Singh (Om Puri) yet again goes to their house to recover his money from Shyam (Suniel Shetty) but they give him the slip. He looks to get into the taxi to follow them. But it is too crowded and hence when he gets in, the one on the other side falls out:  Now here comes the part. This guy again gets back in the supposedly over-crowded taxi but the way he does it so easily makes it look like he is travelling alone in the back seat of the cab.  Now this time Om Puri falls out and while he is trying to get back, you can really see the struggle of somehow trying to fit into an over-crowded cab. You can see the amount of time he takes, wriggling around, trying to get some room. The struggle looks so genuine as he gets in bit by bit:  He now grabs hold of the door to be able to push more and force some room:  It goes on till the very last moment when his entire body is finally inside the cab:  Now obviously the cab wasn't so crowded but as an actor that is what they had to portray. Of course comparing a veteran actor like Om Puri to an extra is unfair but that is not the point. The point is that a good actor truly lives his part and character. He makes the situation very real and responds as an actual person in that situation would do. He doesn't cut corners or take anything for granted.  Similarly there was a scene of Amitabh Bachchan in Black where he had to read out a letter. He took out the letter and his hand reached out to the top pocket in his jacket for the reading glasses. About this, he says- “I needed to feel around in my other pockets to ascertain where my glasses were, instead of my hand directly going to the pocket. For someone who is soon getting into the symptoms of Alzheimer, where patients forget where and what they do, it was incorrect of me to go straight to my pocket. Aah! Still cringe every time I think of the mistake, or see it on replays! Damn! I am such a rotten actor.” This is the amount of attention that they pay to even the smallest of things which we might not even notice. That is what makes good acting. The actor not only has to carry the emotion and situation of that particular scene but also of the character as a person. A great example of this is by Marlon Brando in Godfather, who many a times flicks wrinkles at his forehead as if he has suddenly remembered something, this may not be a part of the scene but for a man like Vito Corleone it is obvious to think about many things at a time and his mind jumping the focus to some connecting chord with the things is pretty obvious. That’s great acting to me. Convincing is the key. Though different people may find a different performer to be convincing at times, on a larger scale a good acting performance is recognizable by majority in most cases. Its like music, the way we rate Mozart or Pink Floyd to be better than Justin Bieber, or we rate a Sunflower to be more beautiful than a dung-cake is the esthetical sense we share as human beings. At times the influence of popular culture blunts our esthetic sense in biases of accepting what we are used to with. Our inert esthetical sense can also be evolved in a more receptive one, through consistently attempting to appreciate the beautiful and invoking. (To mention, I do not agree much with the postmodern ‘all standards are in the perceiver’. I do think of a generic sense of esthetics in people, like the modernists did.) Here is a scene where two greats play. Pacino plays an overconfident son hurried to take the charge of the empire and transform it his way, and Brando plays a wise Father who understands his agitation and hurry, but wants to warn him and give him some of the best educations that he has earned in his life.  That’s top-notch acting by both legends. The actor can ruin a scene by either not comprehending the effect of the scenario through his language, body language or movements or he may seem artificially wearing the character, which we generally call “overacting”. It abruptly breaks the suspension of disbelief that the movie is supposed to continue through out. This way, we can identify when some actor’s behavior is convincing or disconnecting us from the scenario that is to be comprehended at the particular moment of the story. This judgement becomes obscured by the fact that most people do not attach themselves to movie for they receive the story as it is told, but because they consistently try to identify their personal traits and psychological conditions, expecting the characters to behave in a certain way in order to be liked by them - and that gives the rise to stars and their styles. Watch those videos below as a case of bad acting. Totally artificial.  And another one is from this Hindi movie. You don’t have to know the language to make and idea if its good or bad.  He is someone to die soon. A dying man is supposed to hold a torment of emotions inside him, the questions about life, death, a numbness towards the things happening in the world, a distant vision to the world. However Shahrukh seems playing a man whose soul purpose in the scene is to get Saif married to the heroine. A whole lot of expected aura of the character is totally missing. That’s bad acting.
