Acting is doing. Sanford Meisner defined acting as “living truthfully under imaginary circumstances.” What makes good actors seem more natural is that they are really doing. By that I mean the actor is actually experiencing the emotions that the character is feeling in that moment. Bad actors just pretend to be having emotional experiences (we call this indicating) and faking emotion doesn’t connect with an audience in the way real emotion does. For example, if someone tells you about a horrible experience they had and the retelling of it brings them to tears, we empathize with them instinctively from a deeper part of our selves because we see the pain they’re going through. The same applies to acting; when an actor is really, truly experiencing the emotions that the character is feeling, we instinctively connect with it and become emotional as well (and therefore, believe them and suspend our disbelief). That is the main reason we can spot bad acting so easily; the bad actor is merely pretending and trying to make it look like they’re going through those emotions when they’re just going through the motions. They’re not genuine and we detect that, again, instinctively, right away because it doesn’t connect with us. In addition, Meisner said “the quality of life on stage is in how fully you’re doing what you’re doing”. What he’s saying is, the more fully invested you are in what you’re doing you’ll have a richer, more believable performance. This includes things like actually listening to what your scene partners are saying as opposed to passively listening just so you can catch your cue and say your lines; paying close attention to their behavior and letting their behavior affect you personally, responding from your truthful point of view so you’re always living in the moment, right now, instead of planning ahead how you’re going to respond. This way you have a more organic, spontaneous life on stage/screen. Bad actors just memorize their lines and blocking, then wait for their cue so they can say their line but aren’t actually listening. In other words, they’re shutting others out instead of being open. One other aspect is that good actors are vulnerable. They let themselves be open and honest, even when it hurts. This is an aspect that can’t be overlooked, because being vulnerable brings a rawness to the role that hits hard. The best actors are vulnerable and open, allowing the audience to see them at their weakest point, and this creates a powerful connection with the viewer and, again, they empathize with you because it’s something we as human beings are deeply affected by when we see real vulnerability. We can’t help but feel for the actor because it’s a part of our nature. Bad actors don’t want to be vulnerable, so instead they try to appear vulnerable and we see right through the thin veil they’re putting up to fool you. To recap: great actors 1) really experience the emotions of the character, rather than fake it; 2) live truthfully in every moment, they actually do everything and do it as fully as possible, rather than pretend, and; 3) allow themselves to be completely open and vulnerable, allowing you to see them at their weakest and worst. I hope this helps!

Few years ago, a movie Drishyam was released in Malayalam which was a huge success and was remade in multiple languages later. I’ll show you an example of a scene from the movie’s climax to differentiate between good and bad acting. Scene: The protagonist’s wife accidentally kills the Inspector General of Police’s (IGP) son when he comes to blackmail them. The protagonist hides this dead body and after a lot of drama, in the climax, the protagonist reveals indirectly that his family has committed the crime. He apologises for the mistake. Let us compare the same scene enacted in various languages. Spoiler Alert! Malayalam: The original role was essayed by the legendary actor Mohanlal.  Look at his eyes. Even when he is apologising, he clearly means to say that he hardly has any remorse for that. The IGP’s son has harmed their family and deserves the punishment he got. Mohanlal emotes in such a way that he conveys the message that whoever harmed his family deserves to be punished. Tamil: This movie was remade in Tamil as Papanasanam by one of India’s finest actors, Kamal Hasan.  Look at Kamal’s eyes, it is full of guilt. His family has killed the IGP’s son and he is extremely sorry for that. Although the IGP’s son made a mistake, he feels that killing is a punishment too harsh. The message given by the two actors is quite contrasting, but both have conveyed it superbly. Telugu: This movie was remade in Telugu as Drushyam starring Venkatesh.  This is a little tricky. We cannot realise what he means to say. It seems to be a mix of both guilt and indifference to the mistake. This may not be bad, but Venkatesh is definitely not at his best. Hindi: This movie was remade in Hindi by Ajay Devgn as Drishyam.  This, honestly isn’t as great as the above three. Ajay seems zoned out, his eyes really don’t give a message. Even Ajay isn’t at his best. How does one differentiate between "good" and "bad" acting? Look at the eyes. They speak a lot. A good actor makes the fullest use of his eyes to leave a message. A bad actor on the contrary doesn’t utilise them to the fullest.

Yeah, this is quite a fascinating question. Years wondered I also thought what should be a proper answer for this. So I would try to explain how you can differentiate “good acting” and “bad acting” but it will all depend how many quality movies you have watched till now. It depends upon three skills. 1.Naturalism 2.Subtext 3.Unpredictability Naturalism A good actor always brings an emotional believability to the character. This emotional believability makes the character more than just saying lines.  And helps to conclude that person on screen is actually acting, he is actually stuck in a situation.  The opposite if I have to give example, Shahrukh Khan's entire filmography is there. When an actor brings an unnecessary aggression it might or it will make you win praise from true fans but it kills the emotional believability from a scene. And this unnecessary aggression also makes viewers feel that he is overreacting to the situation. A better standout example. I recently watched, 'Lootcase'- one of the finest comedies in past 4 or 5 years. Athough, the entire cast performed but let's take Gajraj Rao as example  There is no way you'll not laugh when he is on screen and you'll feel he is actually stuck there.  In contrast, Akshay Kumar's performance in 'Phir Hera Pheri' is one of the worst in his entire career. What separates them? The worst thing you can do in a comedy movie is try to be funny. And Akshay Kumar brought same unnecessary aggression & tried to be funny which was not required at all. Subtext Now, this is a point which takes a good actor in the leagues of great actors. Subtext meant understanding your thought process to the audiences. This can be done making psychological gestures or subtlety or how good they listens etc. “A great actor is always a great listener.”  If you have seen 'Taxi Driver' I won't think there would be any better example. Robert DiNiro took the entire character on his merit and showed us a journey. A journey which I thought would might end up making 'Travis Bickle' an antagonist. That's how great in the film DiNiro was. Unpredictability This is where even big Hollywood stars like Tom Cruise, Brad Pitt, Leonardo DiCaprio, Robert Downey Jr etc struggle to be consistent. That's what separates them from the group of Marlon Brando, Daniel Day Lewis, Jack Nicholson etc. Maybe one can argue that their stardom stops them from taking these type of roles. Great actors forms a loop or mystery around their character and made us revolve around this. And when they does something out of it, audiences are f***** up.  For me, this Al Pacino sequence in 'The Godfather Part II' stands out. In both the Godfather movies, Al Pacino made us believe that his character never use violence to justify his actions. But when he did everyone was shocked and how beautifully he did it. P.S.- The other two would be very hard for you to understand unless and until you watch an enormous number of Hollywood movies. But number one could be learn and understand by watching top rated Hollywood films. Hope this will help you & please upvote. Thank You!!!

I want to share one story. A renowned Director is busy in his work of screenplay and adjusting lights and background. An assistant Director came to him and said that glycerine bottle was broken. They were in the studio and they need to travel for 10 km to get that. Actually, the actor has to perform the crying scene that day and that actor was a naive artist. As it was impossible to get tears artificially the Director decides to pack up the shoot for that day. Then that artist went to the director and said that she could perform it even without glycerin. Director: It is very difficult. You shouldn’t cry with both eyes. In one eye there should be tears and in one eye there should be happiness. It is a close-up shot. Actor: I can do it. Director: If you couldn’t do you need to say sorry to the camera in front of all. Actor: Ok, how many drops of tears do you want? Director: Could you bring any number I pick? Actor: yes Director: ok, 2. Remember 2 drops only from the left eye. Actor: Ok Director: Silence, Start, Action, Camera. She performed it with ease. My take on good and bad acting is when the director is explaining the scene, you need to feel the intensity of the scene on your own and should perform it naturally. If it is crying, perform it naturally. That is the beauty of acting. I think anyone could get tears with glycerine without being an actor. In olden days, for a kiss, they used to show the eyes of both the actors. Now they are keenly focussing on mouth part. Eyes show the intensity more than any other part. There used to be actors who got many fans just for their eyes. If an actor is ready for the facial close up shots during emotional scenes and delivers the intensity through eyes, I would pick him/her as a good actor/actress.

I don’t know if this has been mentioned before. But I want to point this out about acting anyway. The first and the foremost thing that is essential for good acting is — good writing. If the written material is not good and seems to take the character out of character, it manages to seem as if the actor fucked up. An actor can only play a part well if it is written well. I think a pretty good example of this is Peter Dinklage in Game of Thrones. During the first few seasons, he was given a spectacular script. All his dialogues were sharp and every time Dinklage said them, it was as if he was producing a golden moment of acting. In the later seasons, the writing worsened considerably and Dinklage looked pretty mediocre. Charles Dance (Tywin Lannister) has also cited this as an important thing in acting. In his words, “An actor’s job is to make bad writing look good. But when the writing is so good, it’s almost impossible to act badly.” The second part of the quote may not be 100% accurate but the point remains the same. Other than that, there is obviously the way the actor is portrayed. This responsibility falls on the shoulders of the director. It is essential to capture the acting in the right way to impart most impact. A golden piece of acting is no good if the director cuts it out or uses a wrong angle. Lastly, as for the actor, it is important to feel a character and stay in the zone. Narrate lines and it will be noticed. Over act, and it will be noticed. You have to be the guy you’re playing. Not just say what the character is supposed to say with the expression he’s supposed to have. You have to feel it. You have to live it. For this, I can not think of a better example than Heath Ledger as the joker. He was so into his zone with the Joker that we believe it. And that's what good acting is all about.

Basically, if you believe them, it’s good. If you don’t, it’s bad. Granted, that’s an oversimplification, but in reality it all comes down to ‘believing’. As an actor, you’re asking an audience to buy into a fiction. If they do, then you’ve succeeded. If they don’t, then you’ve failed. You can add all sorts of bells and whistles about technique and style, but the ultimate judgement is whether you succeeded in carrying the audience along with you as you tell your story - if they cared about you (and it doesn’t really matter whether you’re the hero, the villain, or the third spear-chucker from the left). Did they buy into your story? if yes, then congrats; if not, then look at what you did and fix it. Hmm. added as an edit: I notice almost everybody who answered this has posted images from films/TV series of one sort or an other. Sorry folks. I’m a purist. That’s not acting that’s ‘existing’ a very different thing from stage acting. For one thing, in film and TV you have lots of ‘takes’ to get it right (or to be clear, what the director thinks is right - which may have nothing to do with what you’re trying to do with the role!) But on stage, your story exists, minute by minute, in front of a live audience, as you develop it and as you tell it. You have to connect with the audience, suck them into your story and pull them along with you make them concerned about your fate (good or bad). That’s not easy. You just have to look at some of the recent big film star performances on Broadway or the West End to realise that the individuals may be OK at ‘existing’ on film or TV, but they sure as hell can’t ACT.

As a connoisseur of movies and an aspiring film director, I basically consider good acting to be the following: 1. Can you get so lost in the actor's portrayal of their character that you no longer see the actor? Two of my favorite examples are Heath Legder (obviously) and DiCaprio. DiCaprio's recent potrayals in Wolf of Wall Street, The Great Gatsby, The Departed and Django (among many others) show an uncanny ability to flawlesslt become the character and "disappear" from your conscience.  Daniel Day Lewis is nearly unrivaled as a great actor. His ability to "chameleon" into very complex roles in movies like Lincoln, There Will Be Blood and Gangs of New York is truly the work of a master. Another great chameleon actor was Johnny Depp, but recently, he's been so typecast as the eccentric and quirky character that as soon as you see him, your first reaction is, "Oh, Depp is the weird guy." And that never quite leaves your consciousness. 2. Method acting, not in the context of being an actual practitioner of that style, but in the realization that some of the greatest actors are able to convey the feeling that there is a very deep and emotional connection to the lines they are reading, the other characters they are interacting with and the audience behind the camera. It almost feels like you're no longer watching a movie, but you have opened a magical curtain and are watching real, actual lives play out and unfold infront of your eyes. Bad acting then, is the exact opposite of this. Of course, bad stories, scripts and directors can turn good actors into horrible wooden automatons, so there's that.

Talking about bad acting is easy, it comes from the inside, you will feel exhausted soon, you will want to leave the theatre and ponder upon your decision to watch that movie. I don't want to offend anyone, but once we used to like the over dramatic actings, as an example I will mention Shah Rukh Khan. Even I used to be a Big Shah Rukh Khan fan in my childhood. Like anyone else I loved when he uttered an exaggerated version of ‘Kiran’. I loved when he was beaten up and still stand up in “DDLJ “, I loved when those director made those actors dance over a wall. But post my teenage days, I stared hating those movies I used to go mad about in my early childhood. To me the defination of ‘Good acting’ is being Natural in front of camera. I don't know how many would agree with me but I feel that's gives a flare to those character. We can see that the fans have abrogated that cliché of acting being viewed as “acting “ Many actors has made remarks that when the camera rolls on, the most difficult part is not to overdo the character. It's about blending into the characters, what it demands. Takes Ranveer Singh as example. He has put on considerable amount of time to get inside the skin of his characters in Bajirao Mastani or in Padmavat! Those character demanded some amount roughness as well as panache! Though I know these kind of roles makes people accentuate the effort made by the actor, and we tend to forget the efforts the Directlr has made. I belive a good director player the major role in bringing the best from an actor. ( ex. Imtiaz Ali in Highway) I am a big Ranbir Kapoor fan, and that is the quality what made me his fan. Especially post Rocket Singh : Sellsman of the year and now I am probably one of the biggest RK fan you will find. Same goes for Rajkumar Rao and Nawazuddin Siddiqui. Their acting gives the impression that acting is easy, it's not we all know. But they does their job so flawlessly. Actresses like Deepika Padukone, Alia Bhatt are raising the bars with every films they do. They are getting their due as well. Now we rush to the theatres to watch our solo female movies. (ex. Raazi). Audiences are going through a change of taste when it comes to bollywood movies. Success of movies like Stree gives me that impression. I am not a fan of brainless commercial stuffs. Its quite simple actually. As a movie buff and someone who tries to understand the art, I seem to involuntarily point out if an act is good or bad. As Marion Cotillard quotes, “I don't think you learn how to act. You learn how to use your emotions and feelings.” Acting is all about manifesting the character's essence before an audience, the only difference being an act performed during a play in front of a live audience and an act behind a screen. One of the many profound examples of a good acting can be inferred through Heath Ledger's role as 'The Joker'.  The precise moment of his appearance in the film, 'The Dark Night', was awfully brilliant. His posture and body language portrayed a sense of nonchalance at first. His lifeless eyes were filled with insanity to the brink and the way he spoke unveiled a sense of fear within the audience. His every move, speech and stare was so effortless and lucid, which brings me to the very fact of Ledger's dedication towards this role. After watching the film, I read up on his transformation, which described his utter involvement into this character. Heath, in order to play Joker, became Joker, by making himself one with the character for a month before the shooting began.  Thus, it's quite obvious that Ledger's make up was just to make him look like Joker. His indulgence into the character was what made him 'The Joker'. Now, when it comes to putting up a bad act, all my senses divert from Hollywood towards the sphere of Bollywood. Not that Hollywood doesn't have bad actors! It's just that I haven't had the chance to explore any. My belief is set upon the mere fact that, a film's base has to be a firm plot and a concrete storyline, be it purely character driven. One of the many examples that come to my mind would be that of Shraddha Kapoor.  I'm not a hater. I respect her efforts and dedication too, but I don't find her to reach a definite potential when it comes to acting. Leaving behind a few other actors like, Salman Khan, Ajay Devgan and so on, who also fall under the dome of Bad Actors, this coming of age actress is nothing but a pretty little face with a childish voice. I avoided myself from watching the movie 'Haider' only because of her presence. Although, when I finally did give it a shot, I found her acting to be slightly improved, but not too absolute. This might arise out of her taking up movies which have a loosely hung plot and a wobbly storyline or she's just not that good at what she does. On the Contrary, I find Alia Bhatt's transformation to be quite commendable.  From ‘Student of the Year' to 'Highway' and now to 'Raazi', she came a long way. One of the many reasons why I absolutely love her acting is the way she is able to catch the viewers attention and engage it, as her character experiences the story.  Her monologue at the end of the movie, proved to be thought-provoking and emotionally stimulating. Actors, therefore, are completely different from the celebrities most people seem to admire. An actor knows how to deliver a character's story and seek the viewers' interest, in turn deserving the tag of a good actor. Trust me, you know good acting when you see one.

Just like you differentiate between good and bad CGI. We can just tell. We don’t know the equation. We don’t know the processing. However, Over the millions of years of looking at other living beings, our brains have figured out what should be “real” and what should be “fake”. Which is why even if something looks real, we can “tell” its fake. It’s involuntary. It can’t be precisely explained. For instance, take a look at the following stills from star wars the force awakens:   Now you already know that the actor isn’t real. Just by looking at the images you know that this particular depiction was churned out by a computer. This VFX shot was done by Industrial Lights and Magic, one of the best CGI companies out there. Which is to say, this is the best that we can do in a computer, and guess what, the audience can still say that this isn’t real. Our brain is no joke. Evolution is no joke. To fool our brains takes something extraordinary.  Which is what brings us to acting. Acting is all about showing emotions. Emotions like:  Anger  Fear  Happiness  Humor  Curiosity  Cunning  Sadness among the plethora of others we feel throughout our lives. Note that even in non-humans, just by looking, we still have the ability to understand, at a basic level, what is going on in their mind, just by looking. Even for a hand drawn image, just by looking, its possible for our brains to comprehend the intent. Just By Looking That is the power of the brain. To fool that is no joke. To convince this brain that this….  … is real enthusiasm, and this….  is real confusion……… is not an easy task. Because for millions of years our brains have evolved to comprehend emotions. Even in the most convincing performances, we are able to tell what something is supposed to look like, and when that something does not look like that, the illusion is revealed, and the magic of cinema is lost. This is what makes acting such a hard job. This is why we can just tell when someone is doing a good job at acting. When we sense real emotions coming from a person, our mind comprehends them differently. You know very well the feeling you get under the angry glare of your Father, or the happy smile of your mother. So how do you do that? How do you fake emotions? How do you “Act”? In my humble opinion, you don’t. We have all read about the crazy things Heath Ledger did to act for the Joker. He locked himself up in a flat, read nothing but joker comics. He tried to think and act like the joker. He literally BECAME THE JOKER.  That man literally became the joker to play it. Such was the mental toll of the role that people argue he even took his life because of it. But the effort shows. So many scenes were improvised in the film, i.e., the guy came up with them on his own. He reacted “instinctively”. He wasn’t acting. And then there is Christian Bale.  That is not a fat suit. He really is fat. Being so obese changes a lot of things mentally as well. His thought process for this character is totally different. To say that he is just acting is downplay the effort.  And similarly…. he is a buffed up superhero in this moment. He isn’t just acting. Those rigorous workouts, all the weightlifting, body shape and flexibility. All that changes the way your mind works. Do not underestimate the mental aspect of this physique. Everything is not just “acting”, in the generic way that we take it. I have no idea what goes on in the minds of great actors when they emote under scenes. And I can never know. But when I see a good performance, everything just clicks. Your mind just knows.  Other answers here show several examples about good and bad acting. And all of them are great….. but the catch is that all of them are from different films. I distinctly remember one scene from the film in “Kapoor and Sons” ( good family movie btw), in which Sidharth Malhotra and Fawad Khan, playing brothers, have an argument. Basically one brother has betrayed another, and upon the realization they fight. This is the same scene, and the difference in emotion between the two actors is night and day. My entire family was astounded at how good Fawad Khan was, and how bad in comparison, Sidharth Malhotra was.  This is a portrayal of betrayal….. not bad, but…  This is real betrayal…. This is the same scene in which both characters have to show the same emotions. Sidharth Malhotra acts better than most of the A list actors of Bollywood, and he is not bad at all in this film. But he is surrounded by superior actors like Rishi Kapoor, Ratna Pathak, Rajat Kapoor and Fawad Khan, therefore his lack of a similar level acting skill sticks out. The movie is available on Amazon Prime and this particular scene starts at 1 hour 51 minutes in. Prime Video: Kapoor & Sons

To paraphrase Potter Stewart, I can't define good acting, but I know it when I see it.  I agree with you about Daniel Day-Lewis. He might be the finest actor alive today, however I disagree with your evaluation of Meryl Streep.  Watch Sophie's Choice where she not only perfects a Polish accent (and speaks German with a Polish accent, according to a German friend of mine), but she exudes a  certain world weariness perfect for her character. THAT is acting. There are actors who are famous for playing themselves. I don't denigrate that sort of actor, because I believe they have a special talent. I wouldn't call them great actors, but they are great presences. John Wayne, Clint Eastwood, Cary Grant, Clarke Gable, Jean Arthur, Katharine and Audrey Hepburn come to mind in this category. Then there are actors who can move from character to character with ease and make that character  believable.  Tom Hanks. Jimmy Stewart is underrated in this respect, especially later in his career. Henry Fonda, Barbara Stanwyck, Al Pacino, Michael Caine, Meryl Streep,  Brando, there are many excellent actors in this category. Then there are the few who virtually become the person they are playing. As good as Al Pacino, Tom Hanks  or Jack Nicholson are at what they do would you cast any as Abraham Lincoln? Maybe Hanks could pull it off. Daniel Day-Lewis is on whole 'nother level and so was Bette Davis.

Good acting is when the actor lives the scene, the emotion, the life, the character I am not to judge anyone or any actor but I would like to highlight one or two great scenes which I find best. This is cult classic super hit film Raja Babu of Superstar and one of the greatest actor Govinda.  During the movie there is a scene where Raja, son of the village landlord is trying to convince his father to forgive his love for insulting him publicly. A old associate of the family is also present who try to interfere in the family matter for their own selfishness. Look at Govinda when counters the meddling couple about how he is the only son of the landlord and also his father’s blood proudly. Look at his face, his proud and confident expression and his eyes, beaming since he believes that he is the blood heir to his father.  But then the lady in anger reveals that Raja was an orphan baby lying on the steps of the temple who was picked up by her and adopted by his parents  Look at Govinda’s face, his confidence disappears and the pride is immediately filled with guilt  and look at his face further when he realizes how much love his parents gave him and how he only created trouble, spent money, led idle life and made his father angry. What a pure demonstration of human emotions with in few minutes. Simply great

I don't want to take anything away from Marcus Gedulds excellent answer above, but its worth mentioning that this may have more to do with you than the actors. One possible issue could be your age. I don't know how old you are, but as a general statement it's true that younger people appreciate nuance less than older people. It may be that the older you get, the more you'll appreciate the difference. Another possibility, which might be related to the first, could be the type of movies you tend to watch. Action movies don't generally tend to bring out great acting, although there are exceptions. If you mostly enjoy action films, it could be that you just haven't been exposed to a wide enough range of different kinds of acting to really get a feel for the difference. There's another possibility, and I don't want you to take this the wrong way. All of us have traits that are somewhere on a spectrum. One of them is empathy. If you go too far to one end of that scale you get people who cry at commercials and can't help but save every stray dog or turtle crossing the street. That can be so extreme that it is considered a personality disorder. People on the other end of that spectrum are completely without empathy, and those people are diagnosed as psychopaths or antisocial personalities. All of us are somewhere on that spectrum, and you may just be further toward one end than most people. In order to really "feel" acting you have to empathize with the characters. If you happen to be less able to empathize than most, it may be harder for you to believe actors when they act. I'm not saying that last one is the case, I'm just saying its a possibility. If you go through life unable to suspend disbelief for any movie, it could very well just be part of your personality.

There’s a story that a very famous actor was asked who he thought was the greatest actor in the world. His reply was the following: “Spencer Tracy. Because you’ll never catch him acting.” I agree with this philosophy. It’s all subjective, but there are certain fundamental truths about acting: they must hit their marks, remember their lines, express their character’s role effectively and most of all, be believable. All of that, really, points to what that famous actor said about Spencer Tracy - Can you catch them acting? Are they believable? No, not shocking, nor controversial, nor revealing their hidden side (most ‘real’ people I know, never reveal their hidden side), and maybe not even remarkable. Because a great actor need not be any of these things, nor the lead, or even a main supporting character. A great actor can be a bit player in the background, performing their role so beautifully that you don’t even notice they’re acting. You take it for granted they are the waiter, the policeman, the victim’s roommate, the janitor. If you didn’t notice their acting, but you noticed them, they fooled you. They are at the very least, not a bad actor, and often times, a very good one. In the end, it doesn’t matter what famous actor thought Spencer Tracy was the greatest, nor does it matter whether or not Spencer Tracy was the greatest. What does matter is, great acting is being able to fool the audience into thinking you are who you pretend to be. And never, ever shattering that illusion, even for a second. And that’s what acting is all about, Charlie Brown. Cheers from Tokyo. Robbie Reilly As a post-script here are a few examples of what I feel to be truly superb acting performances (not just in certain scenes, but consistently throughout the entire film): Jimmy Stewart in “It’s a Wonderful Life” Audrey Hepburn in “Roman Holiday” John Cazale and James Caan in “The Godfather” John Candy in “Planes, Trains, Automobiles” Kate Hepburn in “The Philadelphia Story” Ben Cross in “Chariots of Fire” Roy Scheider and Robert Shaw in “Jaws” Peter Riegert in “Local Hero” Mel Gibson in “Braveheart” Jack Lemmon in “The Apartment” Kevin Kline in “Sophie’s Choice” Brian Donlevy in “Beau Geste” Jack Nicholson in “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” George C. Scott in “Dr. Strangelove” (I know Peter Sellers is often cited for his 3 separate roles in this, and as much as I loved Peter’s performance, I could feel he was performing, acting, rather than making me believe him. I loved him, but I didn’t believe him. I think George Scott stole every one of the scenes he appeared in). As for your point about Tom Cruise, I think he did an excellent job in “War of the Worlds”. He’s a very good actor, there’s no denying it. He knows what he’s good at, and often plays to that. By the way, those were in no particular order, just the first ones that came to mind. It’s all subjective, really. Don’t let anyone tell you otherwise.

The best definition of bad acting that I can come up with is this:Bad acting takes place when an actor attempts a mode of behavior or archetype that they have resistance to.If we can presuppose that archetypal themes are what a storyteller uses as a shared language of the human experience to get her point across, then acting can be seen as the expression of these behaviors to serve the story. If an actor has no empathy for a prostitute, how can we expect them to accurately portray one? If they are not connected to that part of themselves that asks the eternal question, "at what point will I sell my soul for comfort", they will seem false to an audience that has lived its life viewing these struggles in the real world.Examples of archetypal struggles are everywhere in films and on tv but a particularly excellent example of this is the Walter White character from Breaking Bad. Walter's journey is so compelling because he has a multitude of archetypal struggles happening all the time. At any one moment, we could be shown the Father, theBully(coward), the Visionary/alchemist, the Warrior, the Intellectual. As the story pushes and tests him, we see these universal behaviors expertly morphing from light to dark and dark to light; what Walter White would never do, what Walter White always does. Bryan Cranston's acting is considered "great" because he shows us what he could be like, if he were in those same circumstances. This ability starts with empathy.We are endlessly hungry for these stories because they reaffirm a universal connection to our fellow human beings.A recent example of this not working as well comes from one of our most talented comedic actors, Vince Vaughn. His performance in True Detective is apparently one of the show's weakest. I would offer the idea that this poor performance is due to him attempting a mode of behavior that is not his own. He's "trying it on" and we all see it as clear as an ill-fitting suit.To sum it up, I would say a great actor is one who has either always had or has found empathy for his character's archetypal struggle. Also, range could be defined as the least amount of resistance to the greatest amount of archetypal behaviors.Of course there is a great amount of overlap with his collaborator's ability. A director can make an actor look amazing. An editor has a scary amount of power here as well. Also, if the writing is bad or confusing, we may chalk that up as bad acting, too.Another way to answer this could be from a behind-the-camera perspective. Having shot more than a few short scenes, I'm always very impressed with an actor who can reset each take, without allowing any previous takes to affect their performance. A great actor understands that as film-makers we can only use one take, therefore there are no mistakes, only takes we cannot use. A great actor understands this and experiments and stays fresh until we get that one take that shows us something real. I don't care about a flubbed line here or there and neither should the actor; the "good" one's know this so they don't kick themselves and fall all over themselves to apologize. They know what the job is; they reset and perform.

While acting styles vary by time period (hammy 1800s productions), culture (telenova) , and specific type of production (soap opera v. Shakespeare) it is supposed to be a convincing portrayal of emotion. If it seems fake it is bad acting. It is also supposed (usually) to be “hightened”: you generally don’t want something as boring as real life. A good actor can combine the two requirements making droll lines of dialogue both realistic yet engaging, e.g. changing emotion within the same sentence or subtly changing aspects of the face or voice. Look at Kris Kristofferson’s acting: he is realistic in portraying emotion but he fails to portray “heightened” emotion so it come across as real but flat and boring. Sometimes actors go too much in the other direction, and heightening the emotion becomes “hammy” the way John Travolta can end up over the top. Compare him in “Saturday Night Fever” (just right) vs. “Broken Arrow” (over the top). In some cases you can see heightening of emotion but no realism, which is even more silly. Actors argue whether the actor must feel the emotion for real internally or not but from the outsider’s viewpoint only the effect matters. If you get the movie “Soapdish” you can see good actors showing you good acting, exaggerated soap opera acting, and bad acting (intentional) all in the same movie. Anytime you see a movie where they show actors acting you usually can see them intentionally portray somebody whom is a bad actor or sometimes just good ones as in “Birdman” with a play within a play. Most soap operas have a few bad actors mixed in with good ones, both showing exaggerated acting styles; the bad ones are like you doing it: flat, stiff, unconvincing.

This is a matter of personal taste. There are trends. There are many people who love Shahrukh Khan's acting. But if you don’t, you’re not wrong. At worst, you’re eccentric. So I am going to answer this question as per my personal taste of what I feel is good and bad acting. I'll state a few parameters on which I judge what's good and bad acting to me. Here are the parameters:- 1- An actor needs to come off as authentic and not fake it An actor needs to actually go through everything that his character is going through. It mostly is the psychological stuff like “he is really crying?” or “he is really in love” or "he is really scared?" One actor who completely fails in this parameter is Salman Khan.  Considering this parameter I feel Shahid Kapoor really indulges in the character he is playing and the expressions he gives seem quite realistic.  2- The actor doesn't have to boring and predictable and needs to surprise the audience Seeming real is a requirement, but a second requirement is that I can’t predict their every reaction before they have them. Think of how someone might react if his or her significant other ends the relationship. There are many, many truthful ways. Ways that would seem like a human being reacting and not like a space alien behaving in some bizarre, unbelievable way. Take this scene from Haider where shahid completely goes insaan after he learns the truth of his father’s death. This was unpredictable from him and I was quite suprised to see him act this way.  3- Whatever is being said to them physically affecting them, as if the words are slapping them across the face. It’s fascinating to watch actors when they’re not speaking. Some are too caught up in ego or trying to remember the next line or in technicalities to totally focus on whomever it is they’re acting with. Others seem to register everything they hear. And make the audience feel that whatever is happening is really affecting them. I'll take two examples here of two very similar roles of Ranvir Singh in Bajirao Mastani and of Arjun Kapoor in Panipat. Whereas Ranvir throughout the movie made the audience feel that anything that is happening in the movie is really affecting him. On the other hand Arjun looked really blank in most intense scenes of Panipat.   Thanks for reading :) Do give a upvote if you liked my answer

It’s sometimes depends on the films or plays themselves and also a director to guide the actor through what they should convey for a scene. There are tons of books about how acting to many is structured and how it can come off as phoney, but there is a lot of evidence that has shown a lot of things about acting comes down to people’s personal taste or how the actor presents the performance. Because there are a ton of techniques actors use to present a character in different ways. Acting is also presented as a tool for people to overcome low self esteem or to enhance their posture, speech and conversational skills. Not everyone has the same expression of things, but really to me good or bad acting really depends on the range and arsenal a person has for expression and subtly, if a person just simply looks bored when he or she is not meant to be bored, then they don’t have good stage presence. Acting is something that can be learned in many different ways and you can always seek to enhance it if you need guidance. I think some people like to present it as a flight or die type of factor, but like any job or skill it just takes time, patience and knowledge to get in the understanding of it.

Well, clearly its somewhat subjective, because i definitely do NOT agree with some of those listed here as “bad actors”. For me the test is whether their characters are materially different. Take Tom Hanks. He played a convincing special needs guy in Forrest Gump. But he was commanding and sure of himself in apollo 13. And dont forget splash, and Big If i didnt know they were the same actor i would guess they were just lookalikes. They are so very different. As much as i love Keanu Reeves, he is a great example of the opposite. He played in bill and ted, then ted grew up and became a cop. Little more serious. Then pretty much all of the rest of his characters are Neo. Just… neo in the matrix. Neo fighting demons, neo plays a lawyer, ted goes to transylvania, etc. Its just neo or ted. And when they play to it, its pretty cool like john wick. But when they dont… Or another example. Arnold schwartzenegger. He is always just arnold. Or conan, or the terminator. Try watching him in Stephen Kings Running man if you really wanna see how grievously people can miscast a bad actor. The character was supposed to be sickly, dying, and desperate. Oh. And he dies in the book, either during a plane crash or right before. A crash that killed a few execs but hardly made a dent in the “bad guys” Try to imagine Arny’s character failing…unless he was the bad guy, you can’t. Because its arnold. And arnold always wins. Thats a bad actor. As for good. Well, it just depends. For instance, some actors are amazing, when they stretch their muscles. But dull on the reg. Try leonardo dicaprio. Lots of folks think he sucks as an actor, because of nearly every role after titanic. But i’ve seen Whats Eating Gilbert Grape. You cant fool me now leo. Clearly you have range. What i mean is that some actors are so good in a role that you even forget its them. Gary oldman comes to mind. I once had an argument with another Cinephile about the fact that he’s in Bran Stokers Dracula, Fifth Element AND Harry Potter. He insisted i was just being stupid… those clearly werent the same actor. And some define their roles, so that we cant picture them any other way. Severus snape. House md, And some can do both. Severus Snape… same guy is the sheriff of nottingham, and colonel brandon. This went long, but the short version is that if i remember the actors name, but cant remember the name if the character without multiple viewings… they are either a bad actor, or theyre phoning it in.

Any Actor/Actress who ENGAGES you is good and the ones who don't are bad. Let me break some narrow ways of looking at acting 1. An actor can be engaging in one scene and not in the other in the same movie e.g. Nawaz in Gangs of Wasseypur 2 is engaging throughout the movie. But there is a famous scene “Baap ka, Bhai ka, Sabka Badla lega re tera Faizal”. The next line is the scene is “ Chup ho ja bhudiyaaaaaaaaa, Chupppp” . If you observe carefully, the way the second line is delivered shows you that Nawaz got carried away a bit. The second line does not give that authentic and seamless feel. This is what I observed. But then I thought I may be overthinking. But a surprise awaited me In the making of GOW 2 (available On You Tube) somewhere into the video Nawaz says : “Jab wo scene khatam hua tab Anurag mere paas aaye aur kaan mein dheere se bole Nawaz Jo Aadmi powerful hota hai naa wo jyaada overtly express nhi karta. Itna over karne ki jaroorat nhi hai” ENGLISH: “When we finished shooting that scene, Anurag walked up to me and whispered in my ears that a powerful person never expresses his prowess in a loud manner. You don't have to do it loudly” Now this is a fine example that even a good actor can make mistakes in some scenes. But no one will ever notice this. Caution : I do not anywhere intend in the above example that Nawaz is a bad actor. It is just an instance to explain my statement. 2. Another example of narrow outlook is “ Salman Khan is a bad actor. There are thousands better than him” Again he may be bad in many movies like Tubelight, Race 3 etc. But if you plan someday to engage (not entertain) yourself with a movie like Wanted, Dabangg, Ready then you will need Salman khan in these roles. Cast Nawaz, Vicky, Nasseeruddind Shah etc etc in those roles and watch the magic disappear. Also Salman Khan has a very casual way of going about performances in his movies. This helps him sail through some scenes smoothly but that casual way will not work everywhere. It will sometimes hook you with the scene and at times detach completely. Note : Movies like Wanted, Dabangg and Ready are centred around his relaxed and nonchalant way of performance thus they entertain you throughout. Thus he cannot be termed as a good or bad actor. Note: Do not come up with nonsense statements like “These are not good movies. You have no idea of what good movies are.” These might not be good movies for you but they are magic onscreen for many. Keep your choices to yourself. I and many more need these movies after every 2–3 so called “Art house cinema”. 3. Good and bad acting also depends on tone of the movie. Any actor who delves smoothly with the tone is a good actor and anybody who doesn’t is bad. Example: In Om Shanti Om Arjun Rampal in the beginning of the shots was acting in very subtle manner. It is then Farah Khan said from behind the monitor screen “Arjun! Don't be a Brando (Marlon Brando) here.” This was told by Arjun himself in one of his interviews. ARJUN: I was like “Yes, she is right. Subtle acting will not work here. The camera was taking a 360° dolly shot. I will have to be loud ( over the top) in the scene. Now just imagine if Arjun tries to act like Vito Corleone in this ( fig ) specific scene. That would make the scene disaster. How can you do that when the camera movement, background score is asking you to act in a loud manner. A good actor should be able to differentiate these things.    Now in the same movie we have a Shoulder level shot where the camera is still. Arjun tries subtlity here. It looks appropriate.  A Good actor will know what to do and when to do. This intellect of any actor is what ENGAGES you to the film with varying intensity. A bad actor will break your rythm of engagement with the movie with rythm breaks in acting.

Recently, to mark the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi, Rajkumar Hirani made a short film. In the film, Gandhi's teachings were shared by some of the most popular Hindi film actors. Let's go by the order of their appearance: Aamir Khan - Aamir Khan is a good actor and has played a variety of characters throughout his career. But his dialogue delivery, at times, is quite monotonous. The way he delivered his line, it was excellent. But quite typical Aamir. Kangana Ranaut - I'm not a fan of Kangana, but her act was one of the best of the lot. Her accent is a little different, but she has worked hard to make it sound likeable. And that shows. She was given a book, like everyone else, and she read from that book. Her act? Second best. Salman Khan - Salman Khan is a moody actor. You never know when he's in the mood to act and when he isn't. As an actor, he has shown how good he can be with many of his films. In this short film, it seemed that he wanted to do his scene and leave. Aalia Bhatt - Aalia Bhatt won my heart with her act in the movie Highway. She's an excellent actor. But she, like Aamir, gets quite repetitive with her dialogue delivery. She's young and she'll learn, I'm sure. Ranbir Kapoor - Ranbir was my favourite actor when Wake Up Sid released. I loved him in Tamasha as well. He's not my favourite anymore. The way he innocently complains for things while acting is the same everywhere. Even in Sanju, it was the same. In his scene in this film, he could have done better. But it was still good. Sonam Kapoor - She just parroted her line. Every time she speaks, it seems like she is crying. Maybe it's her voice and I have no right in criticizing someone's voice. But for an actor, their voice is just as important as anything else. Vicky Kaushal - Easily the finest of the lot. Like Kangana he read from the book, but what made it so believable was that he evidently felt what he said. That's not all; you'd notice that he used his finger to ensure he read the correct line. Wow! Shahrukh Khan - Shahrukh Khan is an orator. His voice is unbelievably nice and he uses his hands to back his talk. It really seemed like a teacher is teaching. But hey, he does that every time he talks to a group - CDI, Swades, etc.

Bad actors judge their characters. “This person is a slut” or “I play a bad cop.” The result has very little range or nuance. Consequently, fellow actors don’t have much to play off of, and directors and editors are given few choices in post. Good actors think in terms of qualities, dimensions and characteristics. They don’t judge. They might say, “I’m a person who is very sensual,” or “I play a cop who is willing to make certain moral compromises for personal or overarching gains.” Because the performances have deeper roots they offer a range of possibilities, gradations that can be adjusted. Other good actors in the scene can tussle with them because the performances are alive. A bad actor doesn’t allow for much interaction. Also, good actors have an instinctual relationship with the camera. They hold the screen even when they’re not speaking. For example, Greta Garbo at the end of Queen Cristina. I once spent time with Harrison Ford who, when the camera wasn’t on him, looked like an average guy you might pass on the street without giving a second thought. Conversely, I’ve seen extremely good looking people who seemed to fade into the woodwork when on camera.

At the most basic technical level a good actor acts truthfully in imaginary circumstances. He really seems to be doing and thinking what the character is supposed to be doing and thinking. Even little details and inflections in his actions, speech, posture, etc. will transmit the reality he's inhabiting. A bad actor, on the other hand, communicates things he doesn't want and probably wouldn't want to. He looks like he's acting, or he speaks like he's reading, or he has qualities that detach you from the character and its reality (being nervous, stiff, being excessively energetic, etc.) He might even do or say something that breaks the illusion of reality he's supposed to be creating. But as I first said, that's merely the technical basis of it. Great acting is art. It goes beyond what's real, it's bigger than life, and in that manner it shows you profound truth. It's like Picasso going beyond perspective and beyond tridimensionality and beyond realistic colors to show you a face the way you see it inside your head. Great actors are able to make us believe in characters that just couldn't be real, and thusly in the world in which they could exist. ... And there's a thin line there, like with all art. Nicholas Cage constantly plays larger than life characters and gets as many fans as detractors. Jack Nicholson's Joker also gets mixed reactions.

Bad Acting can be defined as that point of a certain movie, sitcom, soap-opera where the ‘Questioned Actor’ cannot keep the viewing ‘Audience’ engaged. They make it feel like they are just plainly executing the script and not putting any effort to intensify expressions of any kind. An average actor is the one who knows the basic acting skills and can engage audience by blatantly reciting the written script but cannot give any unique or personal input. A good actor is the one who can give personal input to a certain ‘Act’ and make it legendary. There are many examples to give you how good an Actor can be. Here we are talking about Late Mr. Heath Ledger. He is not a good actor. He an extraordinary actor. Did you feel engaged to the film when watching it. Did you wait for the Joker scenes to come? Did his face flash in front of you for a few hours or days maybe or months (in my case) after the movie ended? If yes, he is a good actor! He made the character legendary. Yes, he did. Everybody compares other actors who play the Joker role elsewhere to him. Not Nicholson, Not Hamill, Not Romero, but Ledger. Why did I come to the conclusion that he is an extraordinary actor? Well, he is a dedicated actor. He takes his role seriously. He prepared for the Joker’s role by locking himself up in a room and writing diaries like the Joker would. Christopher Nolan said he gave life to a comic character. He designed his own Joker’s makeup. He added many scenes which were not in the script and executed them with heavenly perfection in one-shot. Do you still find him ordinary. Please respect a ‘Classic Actor’. Sometimes I do not feel he is an actor. I feel he is a legend. Whenever I think of Joker, I imagine him. His way of talking , walking etc. He gives me creeps. It’s obviously your choice to like him or hate him. But dont say you can’t find any difference between him and other actors. By the way good question.  The Joker applauds you! Here is an example of Bad Acting as per your request. Nicolas Cage in the “The Wicker Man”. He is not a bad actor. It was just bad acting.

Sandra Bullock becomes the only person to ever to win both a Best Actress Oscar and Worst Actress Razzie in the same year , i.e. 2010  The left side of Sandra Bullock is from “All about Steve” which earned her Razzie aka Golden Raspberry, for her over-the-top portrayal of an eccentric woman obsessed by a TV news cameraman .   An unfunny, annoying, badly written, badly acted comic fiasco and may be the worst movie in Bullock's career. And in the case of “All About Steve” , almost nothing works, including Sandra’s manic, oddball performance. The right side is from "The Blind Side," the true-life tale of a woman who takes a homeless young man into her home and helps mold him into a college football star.    One of the best performance of Sandra has done. The story of Michael Oher and his adoptive family led to one of the greatest movies of the decade. So many great performances by the actors, compassionate and dignified portrayal of an amazing inspirational sport film. She said on Oscar night: "It's the best equaliser. Nothing lets me get too full of myself. I had the best time at the Razzies. Both awards are going to go on a shelf.Well maybe the Razzie will go on a lower shelf!" She is that kind of actress who proudly accept a Razzie for her infamous performance in All About Steve literally the day before accepting the Oscar for her heartwarming performance in The Blind Side . "I think this is an extraordinary award," she said when accepting it. I like her charismatic energy and wit on-screen, especially as girl-next-door characters in romantic comedies.She has the versatility to thrill us in Gravity , keep us laughing in The Heat or Ocean’s Eight , make us fall in love with her in Love Potion No. 9, or do all three in Miss Congeniality.

To me, the crucial thing is an actor’s ability to make you understand the character, especially to convey the depths of a complex and conflicted character, so that you can read their minds, and in some cases to identify and empathize. This requires a skillful command of very subtle details of body language, facial expressions and verbal inflections. There’s a lot of creativity required, going well beyond guidance that can be given from a director or writer. It often means a naturalistic/realistic style, according to present-day standards - but not necessarily so. Different genres over the 100 years of cinema have had various expected styles, and different directors have imposed their own differences of style. It’s not fair to judge an actor against a particular popular contemporary style. One should judge an actor within the context and constraints of the screenplay, the direction, and the stylistic expectations of the time and genre. Also, a feature that is especially to be appreciated, is acting range - ability to convincingly portray a wide variety of character types. And, for comic actors, special additional skills are required, in slapstick and timing. A few examples of actors from the past that have especially impressed me: Gary Cooper - very low-key, but able to speak volumes with his eyes Bette Davis - extraordinary ability to make extreme outrageous characters appear totally real Spencer Tracy - thoroughly believable and sympathetic Marlon Brando - as a method actor, he seemed to totally become the character - any kind of character. .

Its simple. You already know how to differentiate it. The answer to your question lies in the purpose of the cinema - which is to act as a mirror to society, life, personalities, culture and real people's ideas - to portray intelligent, novel ideas and to emphasise important issues. When you observe an actor's face, while he is performing his or her craft, and you are reminded of a person whom you've met or known about in the real world, then your brain automatically reacts to it - marvelled at discovering the similarity in the personalities of the actor and that one real person. Immediately in the next moment you realise that this is the silver screen and not reality, and how a stranger was able to magically send you down the memory lane. It is at that moment you realise that it wasn't real, the stranger was, indeed, “acting”. This is where an actor succeeds.

Marcus Geduld conjured an answer that pretty much stated my own feelings on the question.   Cinema as a whole is subjective.  Performance can be subjective as well.  There are actors that are heralded, yet I still don't care for them that much.  And there are actors that are less celebrated, but I love them.  Tom Cruise IS a great actor in my eyes... look beyond his action roles to the likes of Born on the Fourth of July, Jerry Maguire, Magnolia, etc.   That said, there IS a way to objectively view a performance and decide whether it is good or bad acting.   Self awareness is the kiss of death for an actor.  Bad actors aren't able to break through those walls of self consciousness and become very aware of their performance.  Overly aware.  And the audience can tell.  It's the actors that make those emotions real and effortless, like the aforementioned Tom Cruise and Philip Seymour Hoffman, among so many more, that are great actors.   And then there's the element of performance where certain actors become masterful of their craft and truly do disappear into many of their roles, much like we've seen with Daniel Day-Lewis, Christian Bale, Robert De Niro early in his career, etc.   But beyond self awareness in their performance, yes, it's subjective.  And yes, it's often more about the role than it is the acting, which is why you likely hold actors like Tom Cruise to a lesser standard because as of late (And I'm a Tom Cruise fan), he hasn't had any great roles.  He's been Tom Cruise the action hero for the most part.  And if you look at Philip Seymour Hoffman roles in comparison to his Capote, Boogie Nights, Happiness, and others, you'll see that he plays those characters very different.

Do yourself a favor and watch “Bang the Drum Slowly”, “The Lion in Winter”, “The Trouble with Harry”, or “Age of Consent”, they all great actors (DiNero, Hopkins, MacLaine, and Mirren, respectively) in their debut or first major role. In each case, you can see a seamlessness that almost defies the notion that you are watching something that is not reality i.e. they make the story in the movie come to life. The first time, my future first ex-wife saw the movie “Pretty Woman”, she asked me who was playing the role Stuckey, Edward Lewis’ (Richard Gere) attorney. As soon as I said Jason Alexander, her reaction was telling; she could not grasp the actor playing a bad guy so well you'd forget his other funnier roles. The weird part was her brother, John Heppenstall, went to college with Jason Alexander where they were both theater majors. When I mentioned her reaction to my brother-in-law, his response was amazing, “Jason is so good that other actors are in awe of him.”

Let me give the underlying principle of acting first using an example of smiling. There are two pathways in the brain that can create a smile. There is a voluntary pathway and the limbic pathway. The voluntary pathway is activated when someone tells you to smile (for example for a picture). The smile seems pretty normal but humans are actually pretty good at detecting a fake smile. That's why in photos we see that people are forcing themselves to smile. The limbic pathway is the unconscious pathway that causes us to smile without thinking when we hear a good joke. This is the natural smile because we don't control it; it happens naturally.  The difference between a good actor and a bad actor is that the good actor has practiced smiling using their voluntary pathway so much that it looks like their genuine limbic system smile so it appears natural. They practice this with all their emotions until they can control their voluntary system to the point where it resembles the real thing. That's why a good actor makes it look effortless and we don't even notice that they are acting because they are so good. That's why when we ourselves try to act or see a bad actor, we can see that the emotions look fake. Bad actors haven't practiced or perfected the minor nuances to emulate the genuine emotion and that's the difference.

For a long time, I wasn't sure if I really could be a judge of a good vs bad acting. I mean there's an answer on this thread that illustrates good vs bad acting by comparing Katrina Kaif and Alia Bhatt. And I like both of them, in their own styles. I have been Katrina fan since New York or even Azab Prem Ki Ghazab Kahani. And have loved Alia since 2 States. (I watched Highway much later) So, I am not yet sure if I know even now. But I do have a “trick” up my sleeve now. I was watching Tigmanshu Dhulia's ScoopWhoop Townhall. The host asks the veteran director what he thinks is good acting. He says that when you see a performance and you think that this is how it is in real life or this how it must play out, then that is a good performance. So, I thought about this and my sort of corollary to this is: When the performance creates a stereotype, then that is a great performance. Let's take a stereotypical character like a Delhi Boy that first happened with Ranveer Singh in Band Baaja Baraat. Something that has also lent itself to the stereotype of a middle class, North Indian guy which Aayushman Khurrana plays with such ease. So the performances by these actors have been so good that you can't imagine a North Indian guy differently. Let's take Kangana Ranaut. She has created moulds for so many characters. Right from Gangster to Fashion to Tanu Weds Manu to Queen to Judgemental Hai Kya. For me though, I think Queen is her breakthrough performance. Her character was so relatable and it broke so many notions. I don't think I have seen such an authentic caricatures of middle class, urban dwelling families. And then there are also characters that turn the stereotypes on their head. Like Ranbir Kapoor as a Sardar in Rocket Singh: Salesman of the Year. His Sardar is so unlike the usual ones that grace the screen that what it effectively does is normalise the community rather than make a silly caricature of it. So, these lists are endless. What I would conclude is that the performance that convinces you is good acting and one that feels like an “odd one out” is a bad one.

Oooh, good question. Thank you for asking. Acting is a very subjectve art form, not least because there areas many different styles and techniques. Nevertheless, good acting has what Diick Button calls a “wow” factor - when you see it it is unmistakable. Whether it leaves you in tears, shaken, laughing uproariously or shocked and confused, it has an effect on you. Here are some criteria I use to evaluate acting when I am casting a show: Number one is mastery of the text. The actor should know what they are saying and why they are saying it. They should understand the role this particular piece of language plays in the scene, in the character’s progress, and in the back-and-forth of ideas shared between their character and the other one. Script analysis seems like a simple ability, but reading a script is as specialized and technical a skill in its way as reading music or dance notation. Close reading of a complex script demands intelligence, research, a coherent interpretation, a willingness to engage contradictory points of view, specific literary skills and some sense of history and character psychology. It’s not easy and the best interpreters always find more to discover. For actors, an understanding of the character is paramount, but the actor should not be too wedded to any large theory of the character - rather, he or she should be open to and interested in evaluating the character’s behavior on a moment to moment basis, and excavating each line for maximum meaning, implication, and revealing character information or narrative significance. Actors should be especially curious about how their character is using language to affect the other character, and to get what they want. The best actors find multiple motivations in one scene - and line - and sometimes even contradictory ones. Still, once we’ve done all that textual excavation and interrogation work we try to distill our interpretation into a simple, clear and actable objective. Since actors are often inclined to view a character they are playing sympathetically, it’s also important to look for actors who are willing to explore their character’s unsympathetic traits and motivations in auditions. Aside from making a portrayal more complex and realistic, connecting with the character’s dark or manipulative side often brings to life the character in an unusually engaging way. Why? Because it shows an actor who is able to look at the bigger picture, not just concentrate on those bits of text that support their interpretation; but also because tapping a character’s manipulative side means connecting with their will to win: their determination, their passion, their resourcefulness, their certainty, their sense of morality, their social conscience, their wit, their strength and the sense of outrage, fear, or insecurity that motivates them to fight so hard in the first place. Actors who are willing to stake everything on the character’s single-minded pursuit of a goal are exciting to watch, and very vulnerable. A good actor also has a feel for the script itself and how their character fits into its plot, themes, and juxtapositions and contrasts. Number two is playing an objective. The actor should select a fun, juicy, playable objective and focus on playing that. Some actors like to choose something physical - e.g. “to get you to give back my ring”; “to make you kiss me”; “to get you to come to the dance”. Others choose an emotional need, eg “to make you give me the power” “to make you wrong so I can be right” or “to make you forgive me”. Still others think of an objective as a motivation they start with, but that progresses to other motivations and beats as the scene builds - “to make you tell me the gossip” “to get you to improve my grade” or “to get you to do me a favor”. So in this formulation, the actor comes onstage with a specific motivation - often a fairly concrete one - then gets swept up in dealing with other problems, and may relate back to the underlying motivation at various points, but the scene continues with other issues and concerns as a focus. However a given actor chooses to look at and interpret the concept of playing objectives, it’s a vital skill. A good actor chooses a strong, primal objective that speaks to them, preferably something with juicy language. The scene is broken down into actions and tactics that support and fulfill this objective, taking into account the obstacles therein, the circumstances of the text and the complex strategies and emotional dynamics portrayed in the scene. A good action is often slightly counter to the words themselves, bringing out their nuances in a surprising but effective way; yet based on a close reading of them. Intelligent actors break the scene into beats in a way that captures the rhythm of a scene, the flow of its rhetoric, and the way the shifting focus of the characters develops. Occasionally a scene will have a compact, organic flow that makes it hard to assess exactly where to place the beat breaks. Smart actors try out different combinations to arrive at the most accurate structure. Without a clear, credible objective that makes sense of the text and enlivens it through interpretation, even the most interesting of scenes founder. Number three is spontaneity and unpredictability. A villain who eats marshmallow cookies is scarier than one who walks around scaring little puppies with weaponry. A kind character with a few unkind moments is both more interesting and more credible than a saintly one. An angry character who can mellow out or soften is more capturing and engaging, as well as true to life, than one who unceasingly rages. A smart character who misses some fundamental points is probably a better written character than one who copes brilliantly with every situation or possibility. Furthermore, being loose and open to changes and really listening to the other actor and the text keeps actors in the present and in their bodies. This is what makes scenes exciting to watch, because there is a sense that anything can happen….and it can. Scenes that are hostile can turn tender or scenes that are benign and benevolent can suddenly explode. Why knock an interpretation before you’ve tried it out? Sometimes the most unusual and off balance interpretations are the ones that hit home the most. Obviously, this rule needs to be practiced within the confines of good taste and the text, but good taste is actually not what we want in early rehearsal. Far better to let actors be bold and risk-taking and then rein it in when time comes to shape the interpretation, solidify the overarching directorial vision and create the pacing of the role. Number four is restraint. A good actor holds back some of his emotions. This engages the audience who are forced to guess, is more realistic and keeps a sense of suspense in the scene. Also, the more restrained interpretation is often the more powerful one. This rule is a bit of a contradiction with the rule about risk taking and being unpredictable, but they are both important parts of the process. Number five is technique and breath control. Important for long speeches, vocal variety, strength and technique is a big part of what colors a role. An actor who sounds the same throughout the scene or doesn’t know how to modulate his voice, hit key words, or create interesting tonal and vocal dynamics is less interesting to watch/hear than an actor who has those things. Language and rhetoric analysis ties into this, and I also look for physically expressive actors, with some dance or movement training. Number six is a feeling for the part. You know someone is right for a part when they don’t just fit the casting breakdown but bring something of their own interpretation - grounded in the text, but also creative - to a role. When you see an actor portraying the character with intelligence, interpretation, and a sense of who that character is and why they act that way, it’s a powerful recommendation. Vulnerability, charisma, and emotional depth are my main criteria. When you’re watching acting, take the advice of a film expert I know and just ask yourself: “Is it believable?” That’s basically the essence of it. Then you can ask more questions about whether you like the interpretation, cultural and historical factors, how the actor handles the time period or dialect, etc. It’s an endlessly rich art form. Hope that helps.

Have a look at their name then the list of accolades and body of work accompanying it. A good to great actor will have numerous awards and a massive portfolio of movies. Critics, judges, and “ people in the know” in the entertainment business would have all the same opinion and speak of the actor with the highest regard, they all can’t be wrong? A great actor will mostly never be out of work, in fact he will have to refuse work due to time available. On the other side if you are struggling to even find one piece of work from a particular actor and decide to make some inquiries that should be a good indicator they may be no good. Your suspicions would be confirmed and no more evidence is required if you received the same answer multiple times when you asked, i will use John Doe for example, “excuse me have you ever heard of John Doe”? And they say “John who”? Good acting comes from good actors, bad acting comes from virtually unknown bad actors, although good actors can have an off day and produce a shocker from time to time, nobody’s perfect.

Thespian: Girish Karnad was a rare actor who was not only well read but also admired by people from all walks of life.No wonder, he had won seven national awards; two film fare awards along with Padma Bhushan and Padma Shri.[1] Playwright: Well, his plays -Tughlaq, Hayavandana, Nagamandala,The Fire and the rain -popularized theatre in India . He was not only a Jnanpith awardee; but had also won prestigious Sangeet Natak award.[2] Director: Well, he served a director of prestigious Film and Television Institute of India, Pune (1974–76). Film maker: Well, he directed well known movie Utsav that earned three national awards. It was based on a great sanskrit play Mrichakatika ( the little clay cart) by Sudraka. Powerful : Girish Karnad mesmerized audience with his powerful performance in Manthan- a biopic based on Dr Verghese Kurien and AMUL and milk revolution in India . He enacted a powerful role of a helpless husband in Nishant ; an innocent husband whose wife is abducted by an oppressor. His earned immense praise as a loving husband to a nagging wife in Swami (hindi movie). His role as a strict but also loving father of Swami in Malgudi days- a television serial based on RK Narayan’s book was widely appreciated. Pathetic: Nevertheless; he was hardly in his real self in commercial movies like Ek Tha Tiger and Tiger Zinda Hai ;where his role was minuscule or secondary to main lead actors (Salman Khan ). Well, he appeared in movies like Shivaay ;where his role hardly did justice to his stature . In past, he had appeared in a number of average or flop movies -Divorce,Man Pasand .[3] Few liked to watch him in pathetic movies like Paanch Qaidi,China Gate. His admirers were really disappointed to watch him in B grade movies like Aatank. Conclusion: Good money in bad movies earned him money; good acting in good movies earned him worldwide acclaim.RIP! Sir!Pic credit: GoogleNote: Kindly appreciate it without taking offence.Footnotes[1] Reactions to Girish Karnad’s death | Film and theatre personalities pay tribute[2] Girish Karnad, Icon Who Transformed Modern Indian Theatre[3] Girish Karnad - IMDb

I have a sort of small test to determine decent and not so decent acting. I call it The Memory Test Disclaimer, I have only acted in a play a couple of years ago with some small classes and have not pursued learning to acting professionally (but I do watch a lot of films and tv series!) The Memory Test consists of having the actor or actress narrate a memory, dream or past experience. Yep. Just like that. Sometimes the memory is important to the story, sometimes its important to develop the character. What this accomplishes basically is showing if the actor really believes what he or she is actually narrating/sharing. A bad actor will just act his lines like if he were reading them from the script. Maybe adding a bit of emotion but thats it. The memory feels fake. But a really good actor will make you believe that the memory actually happened, because they too act like it happened. You believe because they believe it. You start imagining the memory they are sharing. It feels real. Most movies and series have a sort of scene where someone is recalling a past experience or memory, even if its a little scene, you can determine how good the acting is. They smile about it, they stop and think about it, they are sad about it, they feel awkward about it, they feel confused, all of this and more are possible emotions a good actor/actress would convey when sharing even the smallest memory, experience or dream. It is worth noting that it doesn’t count as much when they’re visual parts (flashbacks) of that memory. It is also worth noting that this test has a lot to do with the script as well. A decent actor doesn’t necessary save a film from its bad acting or script. I’d like to end with a brilliant scene form a brilliant movie, in which Tommy Lee Jones narrates to his wife a couple of dreams he just experienced.  Like I said before, the script is very important but its the actor who delivers the emotions! I hope you find my method useful! Thank you for reading!
