We watch movies and television programs, so we see actors all of the time. But unless we work in the entertainment business, their craft remains a mystery. A good actor makes it look easy, but not everyone is a good actor. What makes for a good actor? Marcus Geduld, a theater director, responded to that question on Quora, which was then re-posted on Slate. Geduld says that there are 5 qualities that denote the good actor: First, for me, an actor is good if he makes me believe he's actually going through whatever his character is going through. I'm talking somewhat about physical stuff (“He really is getting shot!” “He really is jumping off a moving train!”) but mostly about psychological stuff (“He really is scared!” “He really is in love!”). If an actor seems to be faking it, he's not doing his job. Second, the actor has to surprise me. This is the most nebulous requirement, but it's important. Except for really small parts that aren't supposed to call attention to themselves (e.g., a bank teller who just cashes the hero's checks), it's not enough for actors to just seem real. Seeming real is a requirement, but a second requirement is that I can't predict their every reaction before they have them.

I2A Adam Sanford. An actor's job is to portray another person, and to make the audience believe (for the duration of the performance) that they are seeing the other person. So, how do you know when it's good acting? When you forget that they are acting. How do you know when it's bad acting? When you remember that they are acting. Another sign of a high quality actor is his/her ability to play different roles, convincingly. Sir Anthony Hopkins is not limited to playing characters like Hannibal Lecter; he has played C.S. Lewis and Richard Nixon, convincingly ... and the second was harder because for that role, Hopkins had to lose his Welsh accent. But Philip S. Hoffman (by your description) only plays one role. This is how I see Tom Cruise: he seems like the same character in every performance. As Marcus Geduld pointed out, there is an element of taste.  Some actors, we simply like so much we ignore their shortcomings. I felt that way about River Phoenix.

At its core: honesty. The pleasure of watching a story is getting lost in it, but if an actor is behaving in a way that doesn't make sense for their character's situation then it takes the audience out of the story, which is frustrating. The audience is an incredible lie-detector: the average person has, for his/her entire life, been storing countless passive data on how normal people react to various situations, so you can't fool them. If an actor is doing too much or not enough or is just behaving weirdly then the audience doesn't believe that they're actually going through this situation and so why keep watching?   Most acting methodologies guide the actor towards authenticity and presence, so that they're reacting to the events of the story from the actor's internal truth. Doesn't matter if the story is a scifi comedy or a period piece drama: if we don't believe the actors, we won't care what happens to them in the story.

Thus is not at all an easy question to answer. I think I my go-to answer would be “believability.” Do you believe this person is saying X as the character? Or are you distracted by the division between the actor and the character? Is the actor bringing you into the scene or taking you out of it? Another answer might be subtlety. Can you detect subtle shades of emotion or intonation? Or is there only A, B, and C with this person? Now, sometimes an actor’s personality can outweigh all these things. Clark Gable always sounded and acted like Clark Gable, and there wasn’t much subtlety to him. Was he a bad actor? Well, maybe he was not all that good, but it’s hard to call him bad.

There are two types of acting. I would call it as the physical acting and psychological acting. Physical actors concentrate on their body movements, facial expressions, gestures, voice and a lot of other expressions. They assign each movement, each variation of the body and face to a particular message that needs to be conveyed and make sure that they perform it. Psychological actors take their mind to an imaginary world, think the thoughts and feel the emotions of the character. They are not conscious of their body or face, instead they leave it to their subconscious mind. Whatever they feel will get reflected in their body. Physical actors are called bad actors and psychological actors are called good actors.

I went to watch Sanju a few days back.  There was a family sitting in the row immediately behind, not to mention with their 2 cute little kids. Now I'm sure you'll agree that my seat was easily one of the worst in the theatre. Not to my surprise, those two runts soon started having fun on their own. A lot of people, including their parents tried to shush them - tried to convince them to concentrate on the movie. But they could not care less. I was starting to regret spending my 250 rupees. But then a scene came on screen, where Sunil Dutt (Paresh Rawal) makes Sanjay Dutt(Ranbir Kapoor) listen to a cassette his mother had left him.  It was a long scene. It suddenly hit me that for the first time in the movie, there was complete silence in the theatre. I looked back, only to find those two staring at the screen without blinking. Respect for Ranbir and Paresh has gone up.

Simply put, can you tell they are acting? Good acting does not detract from what you are watching, be it TV, movies, or a play. Bad acting takes you away from the story they are spinning and, if it’s bad enough, makes you wish were elsewhere. Some actors seem to effortlessly transport us by their performance, while others still reach a point where we simply enjoy the story they are telling. Not every actor can do it effortlessly, but many do enough to avoid being a distraction. Of course there are other things that can also distract, like a poor story. But when you focus on just acting, as soon as you think about their acting, they have lost you. It could be an expression, a word, a phrase that doesn’t work. Their delivery could be at fault. But as soon as you think about their acting over and above the story, they are not doing a good job! I hate to say if, but Sofia Coppola in The Godfather III is a perfect example. She’s a great director, but in that movie she was horribly miscast.

Disclaimer: This answer is solely based on this particular scene and is not intended to blame any particular actor for his/her bad performance. The scene I mentioned above is from the Malayalam movie Manichithrathazhu. This is the pivotal scene in the movie where Nakulan realizes his wife Ganga has Multiple Personality disorder and see how actress Shobhana transforms from Ganga to her dual personality Nagavally and then return back to normal Ganga.This movie was also remade in Tamil as Chandramukhi starring Superstar Rajinikanth and this answer is based on a particular scene from the both versions of this movie.  Let's check out the malayalam scene first: Nakulan asks Ganga what she was doing and she replies that she was getting ready to go out for shopping.  But he says she should not go out now and hearing this, she is bit surprised now.  Now she murmurs herself “you gave the permission yesterday, now why are saying this”  Now the husband raised his voice and said she should not go now..  Now Ganga is changing to Nagavalli and see how Sobhana transforms to Nagavalli..         Now she is completely possessed by Nagavalli and she suddenly lifts the cot..    Now Nakulan distracted her by calling her name loudly and she put down the cot..   And now she is changing back to Ganga and she realizes something has happened to her..     She cries and says sorry to Nakulan..    And she goes unconscious.  Lets see the tamil version. Shobhana's role was done by Jyothika in the Tamil version and see how well she did the same scene.. Here in Tamil version, husband Sharavanan asks Ganga to come out with him for shopping..   And she says she can't come now..   Now Sharavanan raised his voice and said she should come. And Ganga changes to Chandramukhi..   Anyone noticed the light around her eyes…  And she started making different faces in the name of expressions..                          And now she is completely possessed by Chandramukhi and she lifts the cot..   Husband distracts her and she put down the cot.   Now she is changed to Ganga and she realizes something has happened to her..    She cries and says sorry to Sharavanan    And she go unconscious  Ok.. Now what do you guys think about both these scenes… Even though this is a very dramatic scene, Shobhana nailed it perfectly by her natural and controlled performance where as Jyothika went over the top with her overacting and spoiled the whole scene by her wierd and funny expressions. . I am not interested in blaming Jyothika completely for her poor performance. All blame should go to the director P. Vasu who even rewrote the nearly perfect scene to improvise it. It is the director's duty to get the maximum output from the artists but here what he did was he rather used artificial lights and gimmickries than the artists performance and the scene ended up as one of worsts scenes ever. To conclude,both these scenes can be considered as the textbook reference for differentiating Good and Bad acting. Thanks for reading. Pls. ignore grammatical errors. Abhijith Vijay Source: MANICHITRATHAZHU - Sobhana National Award winning Scene Chandramukhi Tamil Movie | Jyothika scares Prabhu | Rajinikanth | Nayanthara

Actors that I believed were the character they were playing: Al Pacino as Michael Corleone in The Godfather.Tom Hanks as Andrew Beckett, Denzel Washington as Joe Miller, Jason Robards as Charles Wheeler, Antonio Banderas as Miguel Alvarez, and Mary Steenburgen as Belinda Conine in Philadelphia.Shirley MacLaine as Ouisa and Olympia Dukakis as Clairee in Steel Magnolias.Tom Hanks as Captain John Miller in Saving Private Ryan.Sigourney Weaver as Katharine Parker in Working Girl. Joan Cusack as Emily in In & Out. Denzel Washington as Gray Grantham and Julia Roberts as Darby Shaw in The Pelican Brief. Kevin Kline as the asshole American in A Fish Called Wanda. Tom Hanks as Jim Lovell, Bill Paxton as Fred Haise, and Ed Harris as Gene Krantz in Apollo 13.Kevin Spacey as Lester Burnham, Annette Bening as Carolyn Burnham, and Chris Cooper as Colonel Fitts in American Beauty.Philip Seymour Hoffman as Truman Capote in Capote.Angela Lansbury as Mrs. Lovett and George Hearn as Sweeney Todd in the stage production of Sweeney Todd.Chris O'Donnell as Charlie Simms, Philip Seymour Hoffman as George Willis Jr., and Al Pacino as Lieutenant Colonel Frank Slade in Scent of a Woman.Michael Clarke Duncan, Tom Hanks, David Morse, Gary Sinise, Michael Jeter, James Cromwell, Doug Hutchinson and Barry Pepper in their respective roles in The Green Mile.Morgan Freeman as Red and Tim Robbins as Andy Dufresne in The Shawshank Redemption.Actors that made me wonder how the hell they ever got the part: Jack Nicholson as Jack Torrance in The Shining.Shelly Duvall as Wendy Torrance in The Shining.Matt Damon in Saving Private Ryan. Keanu Reeves in just about everything he's been in, sadly (one possible shining exception: Parenthood).Sarah Rice as Johanna in the original stage production of Sweeney Todd. Helena Bonham Carter in just about everything she's been in.Glenn Close, because she always plays Glenn Close.Mel Gibson, because he always plays Mel Gibson. Kevin Costner, because he always plays Kevin Costner. (Joke: what does Hollywood call it if Kevin Costner calls a studio with a film idea? A bomb threat.)Now, this is just a sampling, but here's the thing. Some of these actors are good in some kinds of roles and not others. Some of them can only play one kind of part and play it well (for example, Humphrey Bogart tried repeatedly to play romantic leads until they finally figured out that he was good at the "heavies;" Leslie Nielsen tried to be a dramatic actor before they figured out that he was really a deadpan comedian and ought to play comic roles instead.)  Some actors can play many parts and make me believe them in every one of them. Some actors live their characters to the point that they live like them for a while (Heath Ledger has been mentioned, for example). Some actors become the character and never manage to completely shed it afterwards (Johnny Depp is sadly one of these; as mentioned elsewhere, he's now typecast as the "quirky weirdo").  But some actors just should not be in movies. Some should not be on the stage. Some should take up a new career in plumbing because they'd be better at it.  Oh, and about Tom Cruise: I think that he was completely convincing in The Firm, and completely flat and wooden in Mission Impossible.

The way I do it: You watch a scene with an actor/actress, and you have the sense that the performance has something about it that seems unnatural. Maybe the dialogue doesn’t match the situation or the speech and movement is artificial. It’s hard to quantify - it’s more of a feeling. The moment you have this feeling, it’s an indication that it’s “acting” that is sub-par and is poorly executed. Now, if you watch a scene and you genuinely experience emotions from it, it’s a good indication of a good performance. You believe them, it makes you say “Wow.” That being said, some people get genuine chills and emotions watching Sharknado. To each his own. Tom Hardy in Bronson, Daniel Day Lewis in There Will Be Blood, Joaquin Phoenix in Joker, Philip Seymour Hoffman in Capote - all amazing performances. In part, they’re so successful because they live and breathe their characters, often remaining in them off-set. Outside observers sometimes see this as very odd, but it works if you really are invested in your work. Method actors feel that if you become your character, the acting and dialogue will be spot on, generating real emotions - and how could it not be? You are that character. Sincerity, imagination, anxiety - you won’t get that from Vin Diesel. Very hard to do, but….that’s the job.

When I think about acting, I think about every day people and every day scenarios, not necessarily just actors in movies and plays, who identify themselves as being actors.   To act is to lie, basically. Actors play make believe, like we do as kids. The only difference is that they think they're doing a very important service to humanity. So you can analyse it all you want, talk about the craft and all that jazz, but in the end it comes down to how well you can lie. What actors do is pretend to be someone they're not to get a desired outcome in any given situation. People do that all the time in real life.

An important thing to note, is that what appears on screen is not all down to the actor. Bad editing choices can massively make an Actor look bad when they had in reality done a good job. What should have been handles or 'fat' on the cutting room floor end up in the Final cut. An example would be Michael Biehn in the movie The Divide directed by Xavier Jens. It's one of Biehn's worst performances. But I don't blame him, the fault lies with the inexperience of a young director who didn't know how to get the best out of a veteran action Star. When you look at Biehn's performances in James Cameron's movies he looks and sounds great. But his acting isn't any better, Cameron new how to get the best out of him. So much so, his early roles are iconic. You can have really great actors but they can have hammy performances in the hands of a poor director/editor.

The number one thing that differentiates an actor from someone without skills or experience is how they say their lines. A person who can’t act just says their lines, without expressing the emotion behind them or putting themselves in the situation that their character is in. Maybe my point is a little difficult to understand, so I’ll elaborate. Every character I play is me, even when I’m playing a historical figure. It’s me, in that situation, living the reality of my character. Especially with comedy, I can’t be thinking about how I can be funny; my character isn’t trying to be funny; he totally believes in what he’s doing. Recently I played a nineteenth century Portuguese missionary. My lines were in Portuguese, which is a language I don’t speak, and I was laying the God talk on thick to a Japanese ruler, though I’m not Christian and don’t believe in gods or the supernatural. I had to say it like I meant it, like a native speaker of Portuguese. That’s acting. Bad acting would be if I just recited the lines, relying on the set, props, wardrobe, and so forth to make it seem realistic. The actor has to do their part. The actor has to do their job the best that they can, give it their all. But perhaps the biggest mistake I see is people who don’t treat acting like a job.

An actor’s job is very simple, but not very easy: They must be believable. If the viewer doesn’t forget they are the actor and lose themselves in the character, the actor has failed. I don’t have to know why the character does all of the things that they do, but I do have to believe that the character knows.They must be interesting. If the actor is believable, but boring, what’s the point. But if the actor makes interesting choices and has an inner life that drives the character’s decisions and actions, it is captivating.Consistently doing those two things is difficult and many actors (even famous ones) are not able to do both consistently.

Thanks for your question, “How does one differentiate between ‘good’ and ‘bad’ acting”, Grace. ‘Good’ acting means the actor **is** the character; he/she is not pretending to be the character. That’s the job of an actor; that’s our work: to create the character and BE him/her - live/breathe/move/speak as the character. If that’s not absolutely seamless, complete and totally believable, then the actor has not done his/her job. In a nutshell, a person ‘acting’ as the character is not real - they are outside the character, rather than inhabiting the character’s skin, seeing with the character’s eyes, speaking with the character’s voice, living/thinking/feeling as the character. Hope this makes sense!

An actor is good when you don’t notice they’re acting when you believe they are the character they’re playing and not the actor, but that’s sort of just the base level of acting, beyond that it’s their ability to take dialogue and make you feel something with it, if you care to you can look up audition videos of different actors auditioning for the same part, and upon watching those you’ll realize that there’s a LOT of variation and personal touches that certain actors bring to certain roles that others can’t, just in how they move, how long they wait in between sentences/words, how they deliver those words, etc. Good actors make you forget that they're acting. Bad actors make it very obvious. My opinion of good acting and bad acting is how subtly (but effectively) the actor is at conveying emotion and telling a story without saying a word. And that the actor convinces the audience of the character’s complexity. That, of course, is highly correlated with the director’s (and writer’s and editor’s) craft as well - the actor needs MATERIAL to act, the director could call the wrong shot (and the good acting could go to waste), the editor could take out the wrong bit and destroy the coherence of a scene (director plays a huge part in this as well), etc, etc.

At its most basic, bad acting is acting that is not believable. It’s really that simple. So why did Heath Ledger get more credit/praise for his work in that film than the other actors did? A lot of that has to do with marketing and publicity. But from the standpoint of craft, some roles pose a greater challenge than others. If the goal is to deliver a performance that compels the audience to believe they are watching a real person, meaning they understand how someone they know, if not they themselves, could become the person they’re watching on screen, The Joker poses massive challenges. Several actors had played the character before Ledger, but always cartoonishly, with little psychological truth. Ledger was arguably the first actor to rise to the challenge of humanizing The Joker, making him someone the audience could believe someone had become.

A good actor is one whose body language says the same thing as his/her facial expressions and/or spoken words. We all have the subconscious ability to ”read” other people’s body language (also subconscious), and if the body language matches the words or facial expression, we get the feeling that it is genuine. A good actor is able to control body language (often subconsciously) to the point where it matches everything else. We as audience members are not necessarily consciously aware of this, we just know that the acting is effective, and respond accordingly. Some actors can do this, some can’t.

Realism/naturalism isn’t always called for, it depends on the project, the script and the style.  What’s always important is to be “honest” with your performance and logical within the world of the play or film. Bad acting occurs when the actor isn’t giving themselves over to the character, but is too busy looking at their performance through the imagined eye of the audience -- she is too busy worrying if her performance is good. Bad acting also occurs when the actor hasn’t prepared and she makes choices that aren’t supported by the script or aren’t accurate to the character.

Acting is an expressive art; the quality of the acting relies on the actor expressing the character’s actions and words. Your question actually has two parts because “telling if its good” is about how the audience member perceives the actor’s work. Good acting is about believability. Human beings have different thresholds for suspending disbelief and this threshold changes over time. For example, professional critics of television and theater are picky because it is their job to review the production. Or, some people see things differently because they play video games all the time. Acting advice for film and television says that if you learn your lines and hit your mark, you’re doing a good job. Acting in a theater production demands a “bigger” performance. I don’t think doing a good job is the same as good acting but they are both important.

Authenticity and truth. Ultimately, everyone will have their own opinion, but the basis of good acting is whether or not it feels authentic and truthful. When you peg acting as “cheesy,” what you’re really saying is that you don’t believe the actor. In other words, you don’t really believe that they’re scared or happy, etc. so it feels like they’re faking it.

Try to replace some other good actor/actress in place of the actor/actress in question. If you think the other can do better job, then the actor in question did not perform or acted well.
